T - Starts off with some wet basement must and a decent amount of lactic sourness quickly giving way to hints of mild barnyard funk, some fresh grass and some damp earth. Finish is kind of a mix of everything with a bit of extra tartness, not lingering overly long on the palate.


M - Medium body with no carbonation at all. The lack of carb leads to a slick, slippery feel that flows freely across the palate.


O - I enjoy a still lambic every now and then but I still prefer them to be carbonated. I like the aromas and flavors but this just isnt one of the Cantillons I would seek out. Great to try it but that was fine for me.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2013 Jag var så säker att jag reda gjort en rate att jag inte tittade efter. Mac bjuder på denna fantastiska pjäs från cantillon på OC . Helt flat, funkig och samtidigt läskande. Vill man ha stiltypisk cantillon kan man möjligen bli besviken men för den som är orienterad i funkträsket är det här oerhört bra. Underbart 


Tap på Akkurat till Rochfortmusslor. Årgång 2010. Fantastisk. Får flashbacks till Cantillon och senaste resan till Bryssel med Isabee. Good times.

A - clear amber with no head. S - musty oak, honey, jasmine, lemon. Horae blanket Juice and vinegar, subtle egg funk, hints of pit fruit and canned cherries. Weak aromas. M - so flat. Light medium body. Thicker malty end. Lingering guezes. T - lemon juice musty oak, vinegar, simple sugars. Malty vegetal end. Hints of pit fruit and white grapes. Honey. O - simple and flat. Tasty. 3.7
Musty cobwebs and rotting wood, cork, basement, tart, low carbonation. Some funky cheese, sticks to the palate too much without proper carb

Cantillon Grand Cru Bruocsella Lambic Bio 2007, bottled: 20 October 2010, at lAutre Oeil in Aylmer, QC. Pours a hazy golden colour with hardly no head, as not carbonated, so no lace. Sour nose with grape and apple notes. Flat wet mouthfeel. A little sour, but mostly watered-down, so not a sour bomb, but quite refreshing. Looks more like freshly squeezed apple cider at the last pour, pretty cloudy. Taste of gooseberries with some hints of wood. Quite interesting for my first of this style.

2007 Vintage bottle shared with Simonsen
Orange hazy, almost no head. Funky aromas, wheat, barnyard, must and berries. Heavy sour, no sugar left, almost bone dry, a bit tart as well, but for the most just very very sour. The most sour beer ive tried to date. There is alot of brett flavors as well. A quite agressive beer - i tend to prefer the more balanced gueuzes to a raw lambic
Bottle- Pour is light with thin bubbles..Nose is musty, tartness, floral, wine..Taste is light tartness, light, dry, wine, soft
UPDATED: APR 23, 2016 This is the real thing; the relentless, mercyless and intense taste of a pure lambiek. Simply brilliant. Try it, even if its the last thing youll ever do.

75cl bottle picked up at the brewery. 2010 Vintage. Pours a clear golden colored body with no head and just a slight ring of lacing. Aroma is woody, acidic, and funky with moderately sour white grapes, a few lemon citrus fruits, and touches of flowers. Flavor is similar. Very woody, pleasantly acidic, and moderately funky with some tart lemons, sour white grapes, and a light flowery perfume. Finishes clean and dry with lots of wood, funk, and acidity. Lengthy aftertaste following a light body and barely a trickle of carbonation. Overall, a really nice straight lambic. Funky, sour, and woody, but balanced and easy drinking. Great beer.

1999 vintage shared by me with some friends in SF on 08-14-12.

Pours a burnt orange color, white head (yes, this had carbonation), thin collar. Smell is sweet tarts, light vinegar, light funk, some acidity. The age has done well for this beer, as Im not a huge fan of the fresh vintages. Taste is funky tart lemon, oak, light pucker, some light sweetness.

As stated, the age has worked wonders for this beer. I would love to acquire another bottle of this vintage, but thats going to be hard to come by. Really good stuff, let it age, IMO!
Flaske delt med esp0r. Guldem farge. Lavt karbonert. Uten skum. Uten tvil den sureste ølen jeg har smakt. Veldig god men definitivt for viderekommende

From barrell at Cantillon brewery. This is the same beer as Bruocsella but this has only 15 months of barrel age. Hazy dark yellow color with no head. Aroma of sour apple and yeast. Raw taste of sour apples and apricot. Acidic.

Aroma: Cinnamon, latex, a bit of sulfur, some cideryness and apple aromas too. Subtle.

Appearance: Transparent yellow, no head whatsoever. 

Taste: Sour, a bit of funk, burnt rubber....

Palate: No CO2....zip zero zilch. Starts mouth-puckeringly sour, then dries right out which is great but its also quite watery. There is a bit of alcohol on the finish too. 

Overall: Usually I enjoy Cantillon quite a lot but I cant say I like this one much unfortunately. It feels like its lacking the refinement and complexity the blended varieties have....and no carb? Hmm....
Smell of apple and white wine. Golden colour, no head. Very sour. Aroma of cider, white wine, dry sparkling wine, grapes. No carbon.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2013 Bottle shared by some random guy at capitol beer. 2009 vintage Pours yellow with a funk aroma. Taste is the bile burn kind of sour. Good stuff kind of flat
Share with Bish and Danny. Wow, really enjoyed the sour kick that this provided. Twice in one night with the old Lambics. Rejoice.
Shared with the delicious Domnik and delectable Danyul. The only unblended real lambic you can find anywhere. What does that even mean?
Bottle at Brewdog Brum. Pretty flat. Has a pleasant sour aroma, but not over the top. Flatness takes it down a notch or two, but its a solid to excellent Lambic.

Bottle @ home vintage 2003. 

Great beer almost like an elegant white wine. Wish i had more than 2 bottles.

Bottle generously shared by the Tampa Crew.  Pours a still yellow color.  Nose is oak, vinegar, funk, lemon, and some tartness.  Flavor follows with oak, mild vinegar, some sour citrus, some funk, and big tartness.  Light in body and very complex.
Flat, even sour smell with golden color.  Tastes sour with even finish.  Back of tongue with lingering finish.   Clean;  this is a beer to be savored.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2013 75cl bottle.
Appearance: lightly clouded blonde beer, no foam whatsoever.
Nose: wood, grass, hay, horse blanket, leathery.
Taste: flat, very sour, little alcohol, wood, brett, little fruits, very dry.
This beer drinks away like a nice dry white wine, its an amazing brew!

Bottle at brewdog Bristol[br¡
Flat burnished gold, sour, citric acid nose. No carbonation. Not particularly sour..touch of white whine, custard,own grass, lots of Brett, burnt rubber, fairly light.

Thanks, Tommy. My first lambic-unblended...which would have meant I had rated all beer styles..but then ratebeer had to add a few styles :) Anyway, sharp acidic vinegar, vinous, sour apple aroma. Very nice. Not much head. Taste is sour, not a very lively palate. Nice beer.

Aroma: The smell is sour, lemon and sour milk, some earthy aromas, stable, leather. Funky!Appearance: The brew is golden, clear, with a small white head that leaves little lacing, some curtains.Taste: The taste is crisp, sour, sour oak, vinegar with complex earthy notes. Palate: Little carbonation, a refreshing feeling, a dry acid finish.Overall: A straight top notch lambic, clean and very typical. Well done!Note: Bottle 750 ml at a De Klomp tasting. (Vintage 2009) Reviewed 2013-05-04.

Bottiglia 75cl @ Boelekewis
Chiara tendente allambrato.
Schiuma chiara e fine.
Moderatamente acida, equilibrata.
Bottle thanks to Paul (2009), amber pour with just a thin lacing of head. Aroma is a lot of barnyard funk and taste is some light fruit and nice yeasty funk.

Bottle, 04/25/2013. 2005 vintage. Pours amber orange, basically zero head, a few wisps here and there on the surface, thinnest ring of lacing around the glass. Aroma is incredibly funky- horse blanket, barnyard, manure- whatever you want to call it, is there in spades; musty stone fruit, lightly soured cereal malts. Taste is buttery lambic, lightly sour apple, citrus and apricot, sour malts, funky finish, wood. Light palate, yet coats the tongue for a nice lambic feel. Very tasty.

Bottle shared with tiong.  rganic version. Brewed 2008, bottled in 2011, enjoyed in 2013.   Slightly cloudy straw gold colored with no head.  Initial aroma was strong cheese, but this changed throughout as it warmed up, offering green apple, lemon citrus, a bit of earthy barnyard, and even honey.  Quite dry, but not particularly sour, just a nice tart malic acid bite with flavor largely following nose, but less complex and predominantly earth funk and lemongrass.  Would be a great food beer...mussels and frites, perhaps, or even a beef roast.
Bottle - 2008 vintage. Pours a clear gold. Aroma is tart with apples and funk. Fairly light bodied and crisp. Flavours of apple, a little vegetal and tart. Clean finish. Good.

Bottle thanks to Chad. Pours a cloudy yellow with medium frothy white head that diminishes quickly to nothing. The aroma is a strong funk and sour fruit. Thin mouthfeel with strong tartness and sour fruit with oak in the finish. Really enjoyed this one.
Bottle of the 2009. Hazy pale orange with virtually no head. Aroma is funk, citrus, white wine, apricot, peach. Dry on the palate, nicely balanced. Taste is oak, stone fruits, citrus.

Finally!!!!!!  After just shy of a year stuck at 72/73 I have completed my style ratings, i guess they changed number of styles today but whatever.  Bottle at Avenue Pub served in a metal lambic basket.  pours kinda ugly cloudy orange yellow and completly flat.  nose of tart citrus and vinegar.  tastes thin of fresh spring water in best way with no carbonation at all.  Also you gte plety of brett, orange peel, white wine vinegar, sauvigion blanc, grass, hay, horse, carpet, oak.  tannic finish that almost stings back of throat.  if i keep my current pace i should get to try another unblended lambic in 2017

Pours a clear golden color with nearly no head. Aroma has a light floral honey note with nice barnyard funk...a touch of orange. Flavor is tart with funky oakiness...seems like a touch of pepper...herbal. Mouthfeel is light and nit very lively...the finish is oaky/peppery/herbal and dry

Bottle. Light hazy yellow with the tiniest white head. Aroma is barnyard, oak, grapefruit, grapes, fruity. Taste is medium sweet and light+ sour. Medium/light body, oily texture, near flat carbonation. Light dry and light astringent finish.

Somewhat hazy golden yellow. Flat, no foam at all, somewhat sparkling. Aroma is complex bouquet of sour fruits and flowers. Taste is somewhat sour; apples, pear, unripe prumes, complex. Aftertaste is dry, little sour. (Velp 201303)

Opened with mothman during his trip to Chicago. Pours flat with some random bubbles sprinkled around the edge of the glass. Light brown orange in color with almost complete clarity. Smells of stone fruit, lemon, yogurt, horse blanket, and light must. Flavor is kinda dull, there is subdued lemon and yogurt. Mouthfeel is watery and bland, there is no carbonation to speak of, and there is a moderate finish that trails off shortly after. Probably one of my least favorite Cantillon sadly, as I loved some of the other unblended lambic Ive had from them.

750 ml bottle. 2009 vintage. Pours a copper color with no head. Sour oak aromas with a bit of barnyard funk. Flat woody flavors. Slight tart with a hint of orange peel. Not really much there for a Cantillon Lambic.

[ASPETTO] 			
oro carico aranciato, leggermente velata; schiuma assente.			
[OLFATTO]			
prufumi di frutta macerata, un tocco agrumato,  lieviti, legno bagnato, cereali, sentori alcolici			
[GUSTO]			
sapori nettamente aspri, ricordano polpa di agrumi, con un leggero tocco acetato, una amaro medio con sensazioni terrose e legno, alcohol nel finale ed un leggero piccante; retrogusto aspro che perdura nel fondo della gola			
[TEXTURE]			
corpo medio, con una certa morbidezza, nonostante la totale mancanza di carbonazione.			
[COMMENTO FINALE]			
"vino dorzo"  lontana dal concetto di birra nel senso comune; per chi non sa cosa beve, limpatto è notevole: dalla assoluta mancanza di schiuma e bollicine, ad una astringenza intensa, dominante e piuttosto ruvida. Risulta ostica, non è decisamente il mio stile, sorry!

Pours bright gold with no head. Aroma of oak, more oak and funk. Taste is bitter and oaky, tart and dry. Very nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark golden yellow. COMPLETELY flat not head whatsoever. Tast is very funky sour. Excellent beer but carbonation would have made it better me thinks.
Hazy golden colour, no head. Funky barnyard aroma. Flat. Taste is sour, salty, citrusy. Nice but would have liked it with a bit more carbonation

Bottle at fletchfighters tasting. Thanks guys! Pours orange with no head and no carbonation. Aroma is pretty sour, plenty of grape, apples and other fruit. Taste is quite sour with quite a bit of acidity. Pretty decent and well brewed just not sure these types of lambics are my thing.
Non di certo la migliore ola mia preferita, cmq questo birrificio ha SEMPRE una qualità elevatissima!

Draught @ Gastropub Tuulensuu as Cantillon Lambic. Rated on 30.04.2009
Aroma is sourish with earthy notes, some lactic acid and hints of citrus. Flavour has grapefruit, some lactic acid, earthy notes, hints of citrus and orange. Good, one of the best unblendeds.
Allolfatto note citriche, limone, acidità, formaggio,  che riscontriamo al palato, con una acidità marcata, ancora citrico. Armonico ed equilibrato.

750ml bottle purchased at west Lakevieq liquors. 2012 vintage... Releasing the cork yields a small pop and hiss following.  The liquid itself is a hazy orangey brown consistency without any remnants or sign of head.  Swirling reveals some legginess with light bubbles formulating but quickly disappearing... Aroma ideas sharp grape and acidic qualities with touches of wood and a modicum of must. Sour in a sense while exhibiting your mustvesic straight lambic essence at its core... Flavors display a continuation of the same with sharp tart grapes and oak focus with a mild degree of subtle bitterness working its way into the equation late. Lacking vibrancy and punch as a whole due to the lack of carbonation.  More wood surfaces in the finish as well.  Medium bodied overall with an almost absent level of carbonation, still and without life although the flavor profile is rather inviting and tasty.  One of my least favorite anthill on offerings but somewhat expected given its nature.

750 ml bottle to snifter (shared with the group; from notes).  Looks good; a fairly transparent golden-orange with thin lacing. Smells solid; more tart than sour.  White grapes, oak, apricot, barnyard funk, and a touch of apple. Tastes solid too; much like it smells with lots of oak and mild acidity. Solid on the palate, but could use some more carbonation.  Good, but not one of Cantillons best.

Draught at Akkurat.
Pours golden without any head.
Nice smooth brew, balanced tartness. Lots of grape peel in the taste.

Bottle at blind tiger. Pour cloudy amber. Light head and no lacing. Aroma is hay, orange peel, oak. Taste is lemon, orange rind, yeast, oak, leather, sour cherry. Little carbonation and thin body. Overall complete lambic with distinct sour aftertaste.

Tap at Akkurat. Slightly hazy yellow, hay color with no head and no carbonation. Aroma is classic cantillon barnyard, hay, citrus, lemon, sour apples, white grapes. Taste has a balanced sourness, little barnyard, hay, lemon, appleskins, funky. Very tasty! =)
From a 75 cl bottle shared  at Meridian Pint, DC.  Pours a hazy gold with almost no head.  Funky aroma.  Bandaids and sour fruit.  Tart finish.

Bottle 2007 vintage, shared with Grippitis and Parksy. Fairly quiet pour, medium golden colour. Funky aroma, lightly cheesy and vinegary, with sour fruits underlying. Flavours of rindy cheese, funky and lightly musty, barn-y, with unripened pears and sour apple fruit, light lactic acidity and bold tartness in the finish (not puckeringly sour). Smooth mouthfeel, with low carbo. Very nice.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: gold pour with no head.  light wood, acidic, faint tartness, and lemon.  very smooth, lemon, funk, basement, clean finish.

Bottle from Maris.  Pours orange with no head and no carbonation.  The aroma has sour apple, barnyard funk, some cherry, a little white grape.  The taste is sour apple, big oak, dry finish.  Wild style.. so flat tasting yet still very nice.

Bottle from Smith Street Cellars. Very enjoyable lambic. Aromas of citrus, honey, green apple, and vinegar. Taste is sweet and sour, with very long length. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Yellow, with a thin head.

75 cl bottle. Bottled on 29.01.2011.
Originally rated on 21.05.2010. (8+3+8+4+16)
Pours slightly hazy, pale orange color with very minimal head. Aroma is quite mellow with rose hip, some yeast and barnyard notes also, faint apricot, some bubble gum and some tangy citrus fruits. Flavor has also mild rose hip and apricot, yeast, citrus fruits. The palate isnt as sour as Id hope, feels a bit watery even if thats possible. Cant quite remember if this was more sour fresh, but maybe this just isnt that suitable for ageing, or requires a lot longer time in cellar.
3245

Bottled. Cloudy orange in color, no head. Barnyard with some sour elements in aroma. Nice. Quite mild in the taste somehow, has some hints of sour apple in aftertaste. The taste didnt meet up with the aroma.

.75 bottle. Yellow, stale, hazy. Nose is hay, barnyard, oak. Very enjoyable. Some orange. Body is soft. Med, slight acidic. Very soft and easily drunk. Without the co2 its like a "real lambic".  Nose def better than taste. Good old stables.-- bb/h

Bottle from the brewery as Grand Cru Bruoscella Lambic Bio 2009. Pours slightly cloudy yellow to golden with no head. Tiny bubbles are visible after the pour. Aroma is lambic basement, honey, malt, wheat, yeast. Flavor is nicely balanced between sour, bitter and sweet, and has malt, hops and spices in it.
This is not a hit you in the face sort of sour. Flat Lambic that has hints of oak, must and white wine. A great beer.

bottled 10/20/11 poured into a snifter glass. this is the real deal, no blending , no fruit, just straight funk and sour. you can smell the funk as soon as you pull the cork. Not as much hay from the brett, more like just wild outdoor funk. then theres just a strong biting sour. this pours a nice clear amber with no head at all but that is to be expected with a straight 3 yr old. the taste is much like the geuze but with a lighter body and an intense intense sour that almost finishes slightly salty. overall this is good and a sour and a score for any lambic lover.

Bottle - thanks to Sean for my last style tick! Pours slightly hazy butterscotch, no head to speak of, no lacing. Aroma is lemony, with yeast and funk notes - barnyard, wet hay. Flavor is the same, only lightly funky, medium lemony sour with a dry finish. Medium body, effectively no carbonation.

Hazy golden-peach colored-body.  No head as to be expected, only a few tiny bubbles here and there.  Nose is strong and defined with an earthy, funky lemon citric character dominating.  Some musty wood, pungent cheese, and sweat.  Flavor shows many of the same characteristics: lemon, wood, cheese, wet hay, sweat, must.  Medium to light bodied, strong acidity, low carbonation, lingering finish.

Bottle a couple years back with James/Pat and more recently on tap at Monks for Zwanze day. Tons of wet wood, foot, dark basement and fruit skin. Other notes of earthy flours, citrus, mango, delicate florals and barrel. Ultra flat body but salivating in the mouth/tongue. At 5 bucks a glass, I could drink this for hours. I do remember the bottle being slightly better when I had it a couple years ago but I was still a huge fan of this unblended lambic on draught.

Brewed: 08 December 2009, Bottled: 07 September 2012. 750ml bottle into a tulip glass at cellar temperature. 

A - Pours an obviously still clear golden yellow color. A few tiny bubbles form around the edge but pop quickly. A swirl wets the sides of the glass and creates some minute bubbles. Gorgeous beer.

S - Lemons lead into some strong musky notes of cheese, damp basement, and vinegar. Less fruity than the standard bio/classic gueuze. Really great if funk is your thing.

T - Lemon rind, sharp acidic vinegar, musky cheese, wet hay, wood and overripe apricots.The finish is of lingering funk. Strong and bold brettanomyces clash with a still body to create a really unique offering.

M - No carbonation. Medium body. Tart and dry on the finish. Very wine like.

O - This seems to be the lowest rated loon but I loved this beer. The lack of carbonation works so well as the tartness and funk dont get lost in a wave of spritzy carbonation like in a gueuze.

Flaska från 2007. LIte skum, lite kolsyra. Inte så mycket syrlighet och surhet utan mer en rund och len känsla med smak av gröna äpplen och trä. Torr och rätt plan i smaken, det saknas lite sting men detta är ett riktigt gott öl med bra balans och smaker.

Flaska från Ölbutikken i Köpenhamn, en 2007:a. Mörkt gyllenfärgad men ovanligt lite skum. Munkänslan är lite platt. Saknar kolsyra och den lite lite krva träigheten och syran. Istället rund, len, lätt sötma, snäll syra, syrliga äpplen, mycket trä och torr siderkaraktär. Fina smaker, bra balans men kanske i snällaste laget.

750ml bottle [2008]. Clear golden colour with no head. Tart aroma with notes of leather, a minimally sweet fruity touch, grapes, gooseberry. Taste is sourish, dry with notes of leather and grape juice; insipid, light bodied.
Pours a hazy and orange beer with no head. The aroma is tart, sour and fruit. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is acidic and refreshing. Overall a good beer.
Color arancio, schiuma praticamente assente, liscia, al naso note acide, brett, in bocca decisamente buona, mela verde, miele, aspra nel finale.

09-NOV-2012, From Fish & Beer, @Ulkløbben Meeting, @my place.
2008 vintage. Orange, no head.
Malt - hay, sour lemon. Very sour. OK body, low carbonation.
Very simple, very sour. Boring but OK.

Bottle, label says 2003, cork says 2007. Thanks to fredrik_ and Ludvig!
Quick rating.
Dark golden, not really any head to speak of.
White wine, tart green apples, lemons, dry.
Medium bodied, almost flat.
Very nice paired with fish!
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 2006.  Clear gold.  No head.  Very sour.  Quite tart.  Delicious.  Low carbonation.Earthy taste at the end with lingering sourness.  Well rounded.   Thanks vyvvy!
Bottle shared by Colin, thanks bro.  Clear pale yellow pour with no head.  Tart citrus aromas.  Dry with little or no carbonation.  Tart citrus, sour lemon, and classic lambic notes.  Very nice....

Flaska @ Akkurat, Sthlm. Flaskan buteljerad 20/10-10. Ser ut som en äppeljuice, med samma minimala skum. Doftar också gröna äpplen, samt vinäger och citron. Riktig sur munkänsla till att börja med, sedan fyller samma dofter som i aromen på.

Old backlog rating, 2003 bottle. 
Cloudy green golden, low head. Citric, some sponge and leather, dry horseblanket. Very dry mouthfeel, relatively light body. Citrus, dry horseblanket aftertaste. Quick finish. Slightly one-dimensional.

Bottle shared at Håndverkerstuene, september 21st 2012. Muddy golden body, no head. Aroma of apples, wood and leather. Taste of berries, apples, yeasty, with oak and grain. Not very sour, pleasant swallow with a pretty dry aftertaste.
UPDATED: OCT 19, 2012 160512 @ DØE Århus Syd tasting: Stylish bottle, ikret with cork and capsule. Almost non-carbonated. Not as tart as you might expect, actually a bit boring.
its verry close to a withe wine. i think it would pair so good with seefood! prawns, lobster or whatever!

Draught @ Akkurat, Stockholm
2008 vintage, originally rated on 05.10.2012 - Pours light orange with a small tiny head. Aroma of tart fruits, berries, hints of hops and malts. Taste is sour with notes of tart berries, fruits and spices. Finish is tart and slightliy sour with berries. Nice, quite well balanced and tasty lambic.
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2014 2012.10.06 - sample at brewery (brouwkwintessens Cantillon) - nice kickoff of the day

23.08.2012. 0,75l Bottle. Patricks Pub, Kristiansand. Thanks to Beer3000 for digging this beer out of their beer Cellar!! Cantillon Brouschella!!!!!! Golden orange. No head! Stored in a hot place. Sour wheaty. Earth. More sour flavours. This is the last one of the beer styles I have not tasted!!! Congrats to me!!!
Bottle shared at harvest festival.  Very tasty stuff.  Nice tartness and funk with some lemon, and apple notes with a bone dry finish.  Highly drinkable and very tasty.

bottle share at hill farmstead. almost clear golden without a head. vinous, tart apricots and grapes, funk - brett-like, yeasty, hint of sweetness, light to medium acidity. no carbonation, light to medium body. good mouthfeel. nice.
hill farmstead bottle share, this one I liked a lot, sweet and  funky.  The lack of carbonation doesnt bother me. Cantillion really does this style well.
Olut lorahtaa lasiinkeltaisena ja vaahdottomana. Tuoksultaan se on hapan, yrttinen, marjainen ja maanläheinen. Maku taasen on puinen ja happamahko. Tässä gueuzessa ei hiilihappoja ole.

2009 Bottle @ The White Horse. Pours an absolutely still deep gold color with no head whatsoever. The nose is mild chamomile tea, some soft sugary sherbet, honey baked bread, slight horse blanket funk. The taste is sweet pear, apple cider vinegar, pillowy marshmallow. These sweet flavors are reigned in by soft tart flavors. Some "horses sweat n cats pee" action. Light body, very soft. Overall, quite nice.

Picked up 4 of these in Belgium. Glad they all made it home safely. Enjoyed in a Riedel Grand Cru Bordeaux glass. Beer was stored upright as I knew Id be drinking it sooner than the others. Bottled January 19th, 2012 so VERY fresh. I picked this up at De Hopduvel Gent in May of this year. Paid 7,60 Euro per bottle. 75CL Format.

A - So the clarity in this is AWESOME! Hints of clouds but very very hard to see unless in the perfect light. Sort of a dark golden brown appearance. Absolutely completely still. Zero carbonation, no head, nothing. Totally flat. 

S - Smells exactly like Cantillons Oude Lambeek that we had in Belgium. Lots of horseblanket, hint of wheat scent and a nice big tangy citrus aroma. I get some orange peel and honey as well. 

T - Very great taste! Theres a significant amount of oak at the finish. Some bit of metallic like a copper penny taste. Tons of (need I even say it) funk and tartness. Very mellow (naturally) compared to the young unblended lambic Ive had. Hint of sweetness, very earthy and the metallic taste is getting on my nerves a bit. END of glass (dregs) taste. WHOA. I had to come back to add some tasting notes for the end. Dregs arent clumpy at all. Just adds a darker cloudiness to the beer. Taste of the dregs is like candied apples! Very sweet, earthy and tart pear and candied apples taste. Its pretty remarkable. Dregs rarely taste better than the rest of the bottle. 

M - No carbonation, light body.

O - This is fantastic but also very confusing. I expected carbonation in this unblended lambic but its not there. Its not as if thats a bad thing but its jut unexpected. Very drinkable and this 750ML is no issue with finishing.

Bottle from Hopduvel , 2012 vintage 
Head: nothing 
Colour: little hazy mustard yellow 
Smell: typical lambic aroma , little bit of sourness and apples, some malts 
Taste: little nuty , some sourness, mainly some grape skins like bitterness and freshness, good !

750ml bottle from a private order.almost still golden. deep aged woody, acidic, nose. flavour is similar. tons of barrel wood in both the nose and flavour. this is my first still, unblended, bottled lambic and although its  highly enjoyable i prefer the elegance of a proper gueuze more then this. fun to try.

Bottle shared at Moeder Lambic.  Pouts almost clear golden with barely any head.  Aroma of barnyard, horse blanket, citrus and fruits.  Flavour is medium to heavy sour, but subdued due to being the old Lambic only, with less mouth puckering.
Pours golden with no head. Aroma is acidic, light leather, fruty notes and light grassy notes. Flavour is light acidic, sweet fruity notes and leather.

750 mL bottle, bottled 5 Sept. 2007. Pours a clear bronze color with a very thin white head. Aroma of tart citrs, funk, a note similar to menthol or eucalyptus, and a peppery note. The taste is citrus, berries, funk, herbal notes, that menthol note again, caramel and wood. Medium bodied. Very nice.

Bottle at Cambrinus, Brugge - 08/07/12.
Golden yellow pour with slight haze and no head.
White wine on the nose, oak, grandads shed.
Tarte, green fruit, funk, oak, sour.
Medium bodied, smooth, no carbonation to speak of.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Bottle from
Ølbutikken. Pours clear Golden no head, aroma loads of wood notes. Sawdust,  smells like an old sauna, dusty, musty, leathery, Brett and lacto notes, oak,  stable and rural. Rotten apples, and some acidic notes as well. Taste. No carbonation, bitter fruity, very dry, green apples, cheesy, musty, oak, dandelion and leather, extremely dry. Dry lemon and apple cider vinegar.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours clear blond, no head. Aroma is of funk, barnyard, sligth acidity, bretts, sourness. Taste is of funk, barnyard, sligth acidity, water, bretts. Carbonation is flat. Overall: Fair lambic.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2014 Had this a couple of times already but this rating is for a sample from a bottle @ Cantillon Quintessence 2014. Vintage 2010. Golden/caramel color with a very thin ring of bubbly off-white foam. Aroma is of brettanomyces, oak, barnyard, vinous notes and light peaches/apricots. Taste is woodsy with brettanomyces, Cantillon lemony funk, barnyard and fruity notes. Medium body. Flat carbonation. Winey mouthfeel. Dry finish. I wasnt a fan of this one the first couple times I tried it, but its really growing on me now. Its super complex and quite quenching. I wouldnt be surprise than this rating go up when I open another bottle.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2012 Little to no carbonatiom and head. Smells very fruity, with some sourness. Taste is a lot more sour, with notes of champagne and citrus. Palate is very dry. I think I have to get used to this one.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2015 Pours a hazy orange with no head.  Looks still.  Smells like foot cheese, funk, oak, sour notes.  Taste is slightly mellow, not a very hard hitting sour, but what it lacks in sourness it makes up with subtle funkiness and a delicate cheese taste.  Very savory.  Flat as tap water.  This is lambic in its purest form... A true masterpiece.  Unequaled by any unblended lambic - bar none.  Truly amazing.

2009 decanted bottle to wine glass
Sour peach and hay aroma. Clear yellow with no head. Just sour.
una lambic ferma che non lascia scampo a bollicine. da questa fermezza però emergono i classici e piu tipici gusti ed odori firmati cantillon.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a clear golden orange color with small soapy bubbles on top.  The aroma is pleasant; more tart than sour, white grapes, oak, apricot, barnyard funk,  and a hint of apples.  The flavor is  moderately sour, tart, white grapes, lots of oak, mild acidity, mild apples. This could easily be an intro to lambics for the masses.  I thought it would be better with more carbonation.

A: Light orange, with little head and no lace. Typical of the style.

S: Hay, straw, barnyard funk.

T: Delicious. Smooth feel. Light citrus with a delicate tartness and present, but mild, acidity. Classic Cantillon funk and amazing flavor. Distinctive and wonderful.

M: Smooth, low carbonation level. Thin, with an acidic finish.

D: Quaffable. Another gem from the worlds best brewery.

Bottle:
Some airy bubbles, no head, just some light bubbly lacing on top of a light hazy orange colored beer.
Smell sour, abricot, sour malty, light barley malt notes, wood, older hops, older herbs, some hay.
Taste grains, spelts, wild yeast, yeast bacteria, dried yellow fruits, a good tartness, older hops, some wood notes and some hay ish sharpness while not sharp, 
Delicious. Smooth taste.
Aftertate of grains, sour grains, sour, wild yeast, yoghurt (sour) and dried yellow fruits.
Low carbo, soft watery mouthfeel, medium to full body and a light watery but good texture.
Another tasty beer from Cantillon.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Helt schysst, men doftar mer än den smakar. Hade förväntat mig att den skulle vara lite mer sträv ! Doftar typ syrligt o fläder ?? Smaken är inte så intensiv men ganska torr, lite syrligt lite granny smith osv. Bra skit ändå! Älskar flaskorna!!!!! :) 2010 glömde ja säga..

2/VI/2012 - 75cl bottle from the brewery @ home - bottled: 16/XI/09 (2012-570) 
Clear deep orange beer, some big white bubbles, dissipates immediately. Aroma: earthy, wood, tobacco, bretta, cellar, moldy, lemon zest. MF: no carbon, medium body. Taste: very tart start, with citrus, tangerines, bitter touch, earthy, some tobacco. Aftertaste: hay, bretta, tobacco, lightly bitter, lemony sour, yet soft and velvetty, hoppy ending.

I didnt know what the hell to make of this...possibly the furthest thing from beer Ive had thats still beer.  

Pours light orange, ZERO carbonation, no head or lacing.  Body is medium-light and theres a ton of tartness to it, and then this finish is dry.  Definitely a sour ale.  

Its different, so try it for that reason alone, but I cant say much else for it.

Pours a clear golden color with nearly no head.  Aroma has a light floral honey note with nice barnyard funk...a touch of orange.  Flavor is tart with funky oakiness...seems like a touch of pepper...herbal.  Mouthfeel is light and nit very lively...the finish is oaky/peppery/herbal and dry.

Location/Date:Bottle on June 2nd, 2012 brought by nickd717.
Appearance: Pours a dark yellow orange.
Aroma: Aroma is yeasty, a little bit earthy.
Taste: Taste is really tart, fruity.
Palate:Medium body.
Summary: First off, thanks Nick! Second off, my first Lambic-Unblended rating(and first lambic rated overall).   An interesting beer style, and Im glad I got to try it.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2012 
Location: Bottle shared by NickD717, 6/2/12


Aroma: This beer has a fairly sour/tart/funky nose, with a light fruit/yeast feel

Appearance: This one pours a cloudy orange color, a flat look, and almost no head

Flavor: The taste is rather funky as well, sour/tart with some yeast and wood too

Palate: This one has a fairly light body, with a flat carbonation, and a dry/sour finish

Overall Impression: 
Thanks for flying this one across the counrty Nick!  Especially this one, since it allowed me to tick my last remaining un-ticked style, and you know how much I enjoy a good tick (land) mark.  Anyway, this was some interesting stuff.  It was not exactly your typical beer, but it still works pretty well to me.

Bottle from Cantillon. Pours a dark golden colour with a lacy beige head. Aroma of lemon, horse blanket, wet cardboard and oak. Similar flavours and fairly tart with a dry finish. Very low carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. An excellent lambic.

Bottled 05 August, 2007
Slightly hazy orange-amber, no head.  some particulate floaters.
Aroma is tart/sour....some damp wood funk.
Taste is an aged fruity wine-like sour.

Bottle (2007). Woody, funky, tart vinous aroma. Hazy golden with no head, suspended sediment. Mellow, tart unpasteurized cider vinegar type flavor, woody, funky, light bitterness in the finish, Light to medium body with a dry tannic finish.

Bottle @ DØE meeting. Pours light golden, no head. Aroma is lightly sour with grapes, dusty, barnyard, brett.  Taste is rather sour with green grapes, light spice, barnyard, dust, yeast. Medium body, low carbonation. 160512
Bottle. Color clear yellow with small head. Aroma sour, grape, wine, fruits. Taste sour, grapes, grapefruit.

Headless, orange beer. Fresh apple cider, pretty clean, cheese, raw but not sharp sourness shining through. Quite smooth actually although not super complex. Sweet end. Refreshing. I could drink loads of this when properly cooled on a proper warm day. (75cl bottle, marked bottled 01-2012, bit expensive priced)

Bottle. 2006 Bio. Aromas of leather, dry fruit, stinky socks, lemon zest, and more (complex). Apple juice, cloudy orange color. Flavors run the gamut from cheese, rancid butter, horse sweat. Funk and more funk with a woody finish. Flat, absolutely no carbonation. Pure lambic with ancient flavors.

[Grand Cru Bruocsella - Lambic Bio 2007] Bottle (75cl) from Vinmonopolet (Vika), Oslo. Clear (or slightly milky) golden/amber colour with a faint greenish tint. No head. Complex aroma of vinegar, barnyard, leather, yellow apple, peach, yeast, paint. Medium body, flat carbonation. Tart taste, balanced by apple juice sweetness. Finishes with a slightly burning vinegar acidity. Very interesting - definitely a grower that I will need to rerate when having gained more familiarity with the style.

2006 bottle, Bio. Clear medium bronze color. Not a bubble in the house. Nose of leather, old hardcover books, tobacco. Flavors of mineral water, oily, light tartness, very cheesy. Leather is the overwhelming flavor, though, with dust, socks, lemon zest or pith, and lots of wood. Very mellow with age and not much tartness left. A fascinating beer that is not immediately approachable or likeable, but that I enjoyed more than newer Oude Lambics I have had on draught.

(bottle) pours a slightly hazy golden colour with no head. aroma of treebark, apple juice, earth and grass, peaches, snails in garlic sauce and light gouda, quite funky. flavour is milk chocolate and wood, very cheesy, with lots of lime and sour dough. medium-bodied with no carbonation.

Persikofärgad, lätt grumlig. Litet vitt skum. Dofter av sura omogna äpplen, citron och frukt. Surhet som drar lätt i kinderna men ändå snällare än många andra lambics. Toner av jäst och trä ackompanjerar citrussurheten.

Bottle sample at the 2nd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks beerandbeyond.  Hazy yellowish with very delicate fizz. Very sour apple aroma, tastes sour and salty as well. Flat, light body and a little oily. Weird.

*(cuvée 2006): Aucune effervescence avec une couleur vin blanc teinté caramel. En arôme, douce odeur de grange, terre humide aplani par le temps. En bouche cest vineux, légèrement fruité avec une acidité étouffé presque absente. Seule lactivité de lacide lactique au final nous rappelle quon est en présence dun lambic.

2011 vintage. This beer pours a light bodied apricot orange in color with no carbonation at all. It is what it is. The nose is really subtle and the sour fruit characteristics are faint. There is subtle, watered down dried apricots with moderate funk. Its really light. The flavors are watery and again there are dehydrated fruits making up the sour. Its almost a neutral lambic (I know there isnt fruit), like sour water. It drinks very light in watery in body. I know its supposed to be still but it doesnt do the beer any favors. This is still very drinkable. It wont wow you in any way but its a nice, easy drinking lambic.

reviewed 01-27-2012. vintage 2009. pours a burnt golden yellow. slight haze. basically no head at all, but this is unblended lambic so its cool. very heavy on the oak, some fresh and some old. light mellow lemon. slight cheese. some skunked funk. deep in flavor. lots of oak and some very tame lemon. tart and sour, with tartness up front and in the back. a great combo of both. the skunkiness really shines in the flavor as well, i liked it. some bitter grapefruit juice here and there. flat and still but very dry. delicious, i can see why this is a grand cru, its good.

Lambic Bio 2007.  Oh... my... god.  The layers of complexity in here are incredible.  Tart, funky sourness, then buttery sweetness, apricot, peach, the classic horse blanket notes... its amazing.  This is so beautiful its ridiculous.  And it looks like butter beer from Harry Potter.  Winning.

75cl bottle. Lambic Bio 2008. It has an orange/yellow/green color (I know it sounds absurd but still I cannot find any other color name that fits it). There is no head at all. Nose : its a delicate smell since there is no carbonation to bring it out, still there are distinctive aromas of herbs, citrus fruits, smoked wood and wood raisin. Sip : Watery low density liquide with no carbonation. Almost no sweetness, totally overpowered by sourness mixed with bitter hops and citrus zest. It combines in the meanwhile very strong aromas of wood raisin. Overall : its a must for curious beer geeks. Although not something I might propose to a regulr beer lover. Unblended lambic is a refreshing drink and could be used into cooking preparations or into blending a kriek .... DUH !

Dark hazy gold with bubbles for head.  Slight musty aroma.  Flat dull tartness.

Notes: Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 10

Gold, fairly bright, no head.  Served cool, aroma is tart lemon and lemon drops, light bitter herb.  Body is medium light (would probably be lighter feeling with a bit of carbonation).  Flavor is much less sour/acerbic than the Gueze, mild, lightly watery (lake-water), light citrus, some bitterness, more than in other lambics, perhaps because some of the sourness has faded which would normally mask this detail.  Very refreshing and drinkable for a lambic.  Still, this is a one-time beer, nothing exceptional tasting.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2014 Lambic Bio 2008 (Bottled on: 20.10.2011) Super aromat biszkoptow moreli i mirabelki. Zbozowo pszenicze smaki, kwasowos potezna tak jak lubie, lekko wilgotny material lub karton. Doskonale wspolgra z jedzeniem. Kolor lekko metnawy pomaranczowo bursztynowy. Zero piany tak jak przystalo na niefiltrowany surowy Lambick. Bardzo pijalne, super podkreslalo smak gotowanego kurczaka z pieczarkami. Kapsel i korek. Elegancja i szyk. Grand Cru klasa z kontrolowanej ekologicznie uprawy. Samo zdrowie i sama przyjemnosc. Goraco polecam w temp. 15 stopni.

Sampled at the StL RB gathering.  It poured a hazy orange color with no head. The aroma was tart and sour with some lemon and fruit. The taste was smooth and fruity at first and then became tart with lemons and yeast. A decent Lambic.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2012 Tasted from large bottle at 2nd STL Ratebeer Gathering, thanks for another valuable rarity! Poured a hazy golden-amber color, still, no bubbles at all. Aromas of rising dough and fresh-baked bread, cut grass, husky grains, black pepper and clove, sour smells of lemonade, flower petals, bitter orange zest, wet earth, composting leaves, barnyard, but smooth. Very yeasty and brett-y. Outrageous sour flavors as well: like straight lemon juice, tart grape-skins and mixed with flat Champagne. Berliner Weiss on steroids. Somehow chalky and acidic at the same time. Light-medium body, no carbonation at all; Im curious how the overall impression would differ if it was spritzy? Words fail me, it doesnt sound like it, but this was profoundly delicious.
TASTED AGAIN 11/3/12: Tasted the one labeled as organic. Brewed 2003, bottled 2006. Still fantastic. Thanks Vyvvy!

A vigorous pour produces a glass of hazy deep golden liquid with a smattering of tiny bubbles on top. Dark apple juice comes to mind. Smells funky and fruity with a hint of sweetness. Tart sour cherries and lemons via for attention against a sweet sugary backdrop. Funky sweaty horse blanket with a touch of plastic phenol round out the nose. Funky phenolic comes out first before a bit of fruity lemony lactic puckers me up a bit. Theres still a bit of malt sweetness in there that tries to counter the onslaught of funk, but it fails. Medium body, still carbonation, with a tart earthy sourish puckering mouthfeel. Lots of raw funk in this one, I enjoyed it, but Ive honestly enjoyed some of the blended lambics a bit more.

This brew poured a hazy orange- yellow.  You can see in the picture that there are a few bubbles lingering on the top.  But really this is a dead beer.  No carbonation.  Just dead.

This one has a lot of the same characteristics of their other beers.  Youll hear people say musky, funky, leather, etc.  It has all of this.  It also has kind of a rotten aroma.  Now you might say thats sounds horrible but it isnt.  Also some oak is mixed in with lemon and apples.  Not a huge smell here but decent.

Now this is where the beer fell apart for me.  I was really expecting a good amount of sourness or tartness here.  But it doesnt have any of that.  There is slight sourness.  Not the amount I was looking for though.  This honestly might be a great gateway beer into the rest of their lineup.  Especially for someone who really has not experienced a sour kind of beer.  Now the homebrewers out there who read this, is it not as sour because its unblended?  Do these lambics get more and more sour as you blend in other batches of lambics?  Back to the taste.  Mixed in with the small amount of sour, the biggest thing I picked up were apples.  What followed was some citrus, lemon, and white wine notes.  Overall decent, but kind of boring when it comes to  Cantillon.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied but like I mentioned dead.

750ml green bottle, capped and corked. 2007 vintage, Bottled jan 27 2011. Golden pour, light haze. Even a vigourous pour couldnt raise a head - a few whitish bubbles and then nothing. expected sour nose, grapey, tart lemons. In the mouth the beer shows plenty of sourness, lemon peel notes, sharp acidic finish, a little woody character at the end. Medium bodied, carbonation is pretty much absent here. Overall this was quite a bit more mellow and a bit less sour than I was expecting, but the key lambic notes are present. The stillness if this beer is a little strange, but the taste is fantastic.

2006 vintage, rated 21/1/12.
Beutiful orange colour, no head. Interesting and complex aroma mixes red currants, gooseberry, perfumy strawberry and floral notes with wood and bugs. Lots of leathery brett, light in lactic acidity. Nice and earthy, reminds me of damp cellar. Flavor is lightly sour, berryish and woody. Dry finish with lots of brett and some peppery spiciness. Smooth, oily and flat texture.
UPDATED: APR 9, 2016 Bottle. Hazy orange body with a small white head. Aroma is tart, fruity notes. Flavor is sour apples and notes of wood, vinegar notes.
[Rated 06/04/2010] A very good lambic. Unlike the geuze, it is not sour and is very drinkable and nice.

Bottle, home - Vitage 2006. Deep orange darker yellow coloured beer with no carbonation what so ever and no head (just hints of white). Earthy somewhat fruity tart and slight cask hinted nose. Full palate. Cleaning the palate immediateley. Finish is tart fruity with a wooden dry almost peppery sweet sour ending. Complex and nicely balanced unblend lambic.
Pours clear gold with no head.  Sour aroma, light oak.  Good flavor, sour but it doesnt linger.  Good beer.

75cl bottle, vintage 2007, bottled 01/2011. Poured deep golden with no head. Aroma is sourish apples. Flavor is similar, very dry, sour, vinegary  with some fruity notes as well. Great lambic, truly enjoyable.

Bottle 750ml vintage 2007 @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours cloudy orange with a small off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, funk and some sour fruits, Taste is light sweet and medium sour with a very smooth flavourful dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle...  Poured a golden, pale yellow with a thin white head.  Despite the head, minimal carbonation here as expected with this straight lambic.  A little musky, some burnt corn and a rubbery chemical character.  Not overly acidic or funky.  Seemed like a watered down Cantillon.  Some barrel character with loads of citrus/lemon peel tartness.

750ml bottle, 2006. Fairly clear pale orange, no head at all - pours as if there is no carbonation. A decent amount of funk, some farmhouse, bit of grass, musty, hints of apples. No carbonation, tartness has mellowed, funk is still present, decent body but thin compared to some other Cantillons. Typical dry finish, sour hits a bit more at the end as well. Decent but would have liked some carbonation and maybe a bit more body. Still worth trying - and fresh it has more to it for sure.

Appearance: dried straw and hay with slight orange hues. No visible carbonation except for a minuscule bubbly collar. Swirls with nothing.

Nose: barn, funk, dust, leather, old furniture. Musty. Grape pomace. Hay stacks and burlap sakes, sawdust and oak planks. Green grape skins.

Palate: little to no carbonation  smooth, silky, and a little thin but in a good way. Sawdust, leather shammy, oak, musk, and pomace. Tartness in the middle  grape skins of the Pinot Grigio and oaked Chardonnay variety. Apple and pear skins. Essence of the farm and barnhouse. Old leather with just a hint of varnish. Soured apples, apple vinegar.

Final Thoughts: I love love love Cantillon. Seriously. Sour makes me happy and Cantillon makes me orgasmically ecstatic. Seriously. Sublime sophisticated humble earthen history is at the heart of lambics.

floral fermenting apple aromas, wood, earth, musty hops, some orange-rind flavors coming in on the finish.  medium carbonation made this feel very nice on the palate and carried the tart complexity all the way around the tongue.  lemony, dry, wine-like bitterness on the finish.
Outstanding smooth and aged lambic with all the characteristics of what a lambic should be like.

Tiny white head. Hazy yellow body.  Deep fruity earthy apple
aroma with funky woolen blanket notes.  Dry-sweet and acidic waxy
earthy fruity taste with oily apple notes.  Mild, soft mouthfeel,
kind of musty.  Mid-bodied.  Dryish mealy mineraly fruity
aftertaste with almonds, wax and flowers notes.  Aroma is great.
Taste is a bit flat and dead. (0.75l bottle, wine monopoly, Vika,
Oslo. 2007 vintage.)

0.75l bottle. Pours a hazy straw-yellow body with a thin bubbly head thats quickly gone. The aroma is really fruity with strawberries, citrus, some basement dust, apples and grass. Really low on the tartness. The carbonation is completely flat and totally absent, while the mouthfeel is light oily. Tastes light lemon-sour with notes of fruits, some woody-brett and sour not just right red currants. Ends light dry with tones of sweet yellow apples. The lacking of carbonation was quite strange and I think this would have been even better if it had at least some C02. Still, quite good stuff this!

Tasted from a capped and corked 750mL bottle at Delilahs 2011 Lambic Fest.  Pours hazy yellow-orange with a thin white head, that recedes rather quickly to nothing at all.  The nose is sour, dusty, classic Cantillon funk, vanilla oak, and lemon pith.  The flavor is intense sour lemon, barnyard, vanilla oak, and some dusty tannin.  The body is medium and oily, with not carbonation, and a long, acidic lemon, vanilla oak, and tannic finish.

(750ml bottled Mar 9, 2010 thanks to blutt59) clear, still, yellow. Nose of wet wood, a bit funky, cognac, tangerine, and candied citrus. Taste is tart, tangerine, wet wood, chewable vitamins, delicious but sour is kept in check here. A bit of a watery finish.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2014 (75 cl)  Le liquide a une robe dorée.  Aucune construction mousseuse nest observée.  Le nez possède des caractéristiques olfactives propres au vin blanc.  Des parfums rustiques saffirment avec une certaine délicatesse.  Les saveurs sont acides et indéniablement imprégnées par le boisé du fût de garde.  En bouche, le liquide a une densité dans la moyenne avec une effervescence quasi nulle et une texture à la limite huileuse.  La finale est fortement aigre avec des fruits et une acidité tranchante.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2012 Bottle. Golden, hazy, very small and fully diminishing head head. Moderate, malty  lightly wheaty and lightly sweetish and sour fruity aroma, green apples and light citrus, some notes of wood - oak. Body is medium, malty  lightly wheaty and dryish and sour flavor, fruitiness with green apples, some notes of wood - oak. Finish is average, malty  lightly wheaty and dry and sour, green apples and some citrus with fruitiness, some notes of wood - oak. Nice lambic - not too sour.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2013 Bottle.
Slight hazy golden with no head what so ever.
Acidic sour smooth vinegary aroma with citrus and apples.
Quite mellow sour taste with lemon and apples.
Medium body with very soft low carbonation. Slick mouthfeel.
Good but a bit too flat and weak.

2006 bottle bought and consumed @ 3 Små Rum on September 26. Pours slightly hazy orange with no head. Looks a little like applejuice. Smell is very sour, piercing in a way. Smells of old citrusfruit, gastric acid and sour apples. Taste is sour with some bitter grapefruitnotes. Theres fresh lemon and some green apples. Aftertaste is dry and slightly bitter.

Bottle vintage 2006 thx to Ned at 3 små rum, cons. 2011-09-23
AR: wet horse blankett, not that sour as other Cantillons
AP: light yellow hazyness, fluffy of white head
F: tart, grape skins, citric a clean lambic

Bouteille de 750ml bouchon de liège recouvert dune capsule métallique. Bière dorée-jaune. La mousse est blanche. Le nez est aigre, quelque peu acide avec touche touche acre. La bouche est un mélange de brett, de cheval, dacide et un goût que je narrive pas à décrire mais que jaime pas. À reboire.
Lambic piatto, senza blend, buono ma molto più difficile da mandare giù rispetto a una gueuze, per veri intenditori.. la Cantillon che mi piace meno. in bottiglia da 37.5 su ilbeershop.it

2007 Bio bottle. Pours a golden colour with no head. Aroma has a slight sourness, green apple and grapes. Body is thin and has no carbonation. Flavour is a little sour, with grapes. Overall while its not bad by any means, its too much like a white wine.

Thanks benzai for sharing this one.

Hazy yellow colour with no head. Smells sour, cellar and wood. Tastes accordingly/ Good balance, long sour aftertaste.

2008 vintage pours a golden color with no head.  Aromas is sour and a bit of skunk and oak.  Taste is light sour, lactic, with oakiness and grain.  Body is light with a dry finish.  Overall, a good sour, but I have had better Cantillon beers.

As the bottle already says, this is more a wine then a beer. This is an unblended lambic 2007, which was bottled on 01/2011. It pours out with no head, which is quite normal for a lambic off course. In fact, there is no need for a head, as I said, its more of a whine, so also taste this one in a wine glass.
The aroma is wood, oak, slight soureness, like when you smell some wines.
Its a good lambic, but cantillon has made better ones. Well see how the second bottle tastes within a year or 5.

Yellow, still pour.  Aroma is funky leather, some lemon, wood, some odd barnyard like aromas.  Mouthfeel is creamy and uncarbed, as expected.  Flavor is lighter than expected, with the leather really coming out, very yeasty and funky, with only a slight tartness on the finish.  Funky stuff.
Bottle, pours a nice bright yellow. Taste is full of sourness. But not too much. Overall its pretty yummy stuff. Very drinkable

Pour hazy golden no head. Aroma wet wood, hay, funk, tart, and sour. Taste acidic with some funk, tart and sour, wood and some earthiness quite tasty.  MF dry light crisp body with good carb. Solid brew and a good unblended lambic. Cheers!

Bottle @ home, shared with DutchDrebus. Slightly hazy yellow / golden color, no head at all. Smell average sour, little musty. Taste mainly sour, but a little mild. Decent carbonation, medium body, very good balance. Very dry aftertaste.

Like the description says on the bottle. Think of it like a vin de cereal. Thats exactly what it is. I would rather compare it to a chardonnay than a beer. Its wonderfully tart, golden in color, flat in appearance, no carbonation whatsoever. Its such a shame its so hard to find.
Flat, very appley, lots of apple and then some wood notes. The thing is, it feel like a dead lambic, its weird, fun to try tho.

750mL corked bottle.  Poured pale gold with absolutely no head or lacing.  Aroma sour, taste sour and bitter.  One of the worst beers from Belgium I have ever tasted.  Totally disappointed, especially for the price.

30/07/2011 2006 vintage bottle. Dorata carica, intensa, con riflessi arancio, schiuma praticamente assente. Al naso presenta un aroma selvatico, agrumato (limone, cedro), acido, poco intenso e poco persistente. In bocca è acida, limone, melograno, miele, resina, pino, per nulla acetica. Corpo medio, carbonazione quasi assente. Lambic ottima per laperitivo, complessa, raffinata, rinfrescante.

Bottle courtesy bu11zeye. Pours a slightly hazy golden orange color. Very little carbonation. Aroma is sour, dark cherries, wood and perfume. Flavor is definitely sour, light fruit near the finish and some woody flavors as well. The sourness is intense at the front but fades very quickly. Dry flavor. Not offensively sour so Im down with this.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow/orange with no head at all. Aroma of hot sauce spice, soured fruits, funk. Flavour of soured fruits, lots of funk, light hot sauce, sourness increases throughout the taste. Nice dry finish. Very smooth. Nice.

750mL bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours hazy golden with no head. Very funky aroma with a semblance of hot sauce / tobasco. Flavour is extremely dry champagne or white wine like, sort of like a gueuze though dryer - extremely smooth palate with no carbonation. Slight sourness on the finish, with the white vinous qualities mentioned. Gets better and better with each sip. I dont really have a frame of reference for this as Iris is the only other unblended lambic Ive tried, though this is extremely well-made.

wow, what a beer- takes a bit off time for your senses to used to it .. Pours a almost flat yellow .. . aroma and taste - wet wood, with light touches of oak and a sick horses sleeping blanket .. . quite amazing how i didnt care for it at first, to loving it when i was finishing it... A cool beer and happy to have tried another unblended .. . Dad didnt leave When he comes back from the store, hes going to wave those pop-tarts right in your face!
Clear golden with an off-white head. Aroma is rather sour - vinegar - and fruity. Flavor is rather sour and rather acidic. Dry and rather acidic finish. A bit watery. 090711

Bottled. Pours hazy orangish with a tiny white head. Tart nose with fruity notes. Sour flavour with sour applesand lemon notes. Light to medium bodied, watery texture and flat carbonation. Sour finish.

Bottle shared by Phaleslu. Thanks Peter. Pours Cloudy and golden with a thin white head. Aroma is lemongrass, pale malts and grapes. Flavor is lemongrass, funk, dry herbs and a bit of lemon peel.  Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

Absolutely no carbonation, as expected.  Healthy Cantillon funk in the aroma.  Delicious crab apple - starts with slight sweet leading into juicy fruit sour.  Finishes with an excellent great barn aftertaste.  Amazing beer... truly an experience.

750 ml bottle from my Summer 2011 Secret Santa- thanks, Justin! 2010 vintage. Pours a semi-cloudy gold with a faint reddish tint and a small white head. Aroma of dry herbs and grains, cedar, pale malts, white grapes, and lemongrass. Flavor of lemon peel, lemongrass, dry herbs, cereal grains, and a weird soap and plastic note late. Light-bodied, with a dry, tart mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. So dry and finishes so quick and strange. This 2010 bottle could probably use a little more age but I was anxious to try this Cantillon Ive never had before.
Clear golden without head. Obviously without carbonation, as it should be. Funky horse, apple juice and slightly bitter. It is rather sour but the acidity disappears fast.

(750ml , 2007 vintage corked).   In my Cantillon tulip its flat and almost lifelesss..but thats  ironic cause its vibrant beer .   rusticity in the air ... barnyard signatures , with,cheesy dead hops that are reborn . citric lemon, apple , and some richness even mingling . . A 4.1 score is excellent of course , but i was maybe expecting a big 4 score . I blame Cantillons alcehmy  , but this was not anti climatic on reflection.

Aroma is strong and fruity, mainly apple with a little pear, and has a pleasant woody undertone. It pours a rich, and bubbly to the point of being hazy, golden orange; there was not much head, but I have had this bottle for a while before realizing it was an unblended lambic, a style I have never had before. Fruity flavor is more like a cider, or even wine, than a beer, but still quite tasty and pleasing, with an undertone of green wood and a sour apple bite. Texture is very smooth, yet a little edgy, leaving a fruity, woody and rather tart finish.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2012 Bottle sample at the 2nd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours yellow to honey with no head, aroma of floral notes, fresh, sourish, bretty with some honey notes, flavor is sour, quite clean with wood, green tea and no carbonation, tender bitterness, medium bodied. 3/8/3/8/14 [3.6] 
At the sour tasting, pours glowing yellow with a small head, delicate aroma of flowers, fresh leaves, cheesy water, olives and honey, flavor of wood, white wine, green tea dryness, a touch of bitterness, blue cheese spiciness, full bodied, amazing 9/4/9/5/16 [4.3]
bottled, off orange muddy color with clean crips tart aroma, flavor is not over the top bitter like Iris, some wood and fruit comes through

Bottle 75 cl, 2005 vintage. Pours clear copper amber with a small off white rim of lace around the glass. no carbonation. Aroma is fruity, acidy, horse blanket, hoppy and slight hints of honey. Very nice. Acidy sour mouthfeel. Flavor is tart sour almost like lemon juice, malty, vinous and vinegar like, oily and a bit floral. Finishes with a very nice sour tart dry aftertaste.
2007 Vintage. Flat golden colour. Nice barnyard funk in the nose. Refreshing white wine flavour in the start, long and acidic balanced finish. Tasty fruit notes.

Verhalten sauer, das Bier wirkt schon etwas älter. Im mittelteil ist der Unterton würzig und etwas lascher, unauffällig, wenig markant. Mittellanger Nachgeschmack. 	 
Test vom 30.5.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: -,10,10,10,11,10 - 10,05

bottle@t Waagstuk: clear orange with no head & virtually no carbonation, upfront it is tart lemon with underneath some slightly sour apples, sour sweet white grapes, lactic acid, sourdough, musty wood plus a taste like the limejuice they sell in bottles, bit watery & oily, restrained somewhat but very nice, tastes exactly like what this is & how you would expect this to taste, a 3 year old lambic
sour aroma,golden, hazy, white foam, medium sourness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Sampled from a bottle at Delilahs Lambic Fest (Chicago, IL). 2009 Vintage. Pours a nice shiny gold hue, a light haze with good sunfire gold harvest hue. A tiny whitish ring of bubbles laces small, die to just a touch of soap lacing. Aromas are shiny sour lemons, lactic acid with bready malts, touch of sour apples, touch of banana, with wet oak, touches of sour grapes. Initial is light bodied, fruity up front with a touch of melon and grapes, moving into sour lemons and sour apple juice, bready pale malts come through a bit with a lactic and yogurty finish. Good solid sourness, more gentle in the finish. Brings strength up front, throwing a lot of sour apples and apple juice around. Finish is tart, apples, and some yogurt. Nice lambic, very apple juice dominant with some great flavors, drinkability, and sour fruity qualities.

2007 bottle, enjoyed at the White Horse. It pours clear golden yellow with low carbonation and almost no head. The nose is very floral, full of chamomile, tart lemon and sour white grape. The taste is floral, chamomile, lemon, red grapefruit, wood, sour white grape, egg and hay, finishing with sweet Cox apple. Another quality Cantillon lambic. I doubt these guys could make a bad beer even if they tried....

2006 vintage, bottle at Moeder Lambic. Pours clear golden, beautiful color, completely flat of course. Nice aroma - sour white grapes, lightly pungent, burns nostrals, complicated, citrus stone fruits, subtle moss funk. Bitterness and sour fight in mouth, Bitter-sour-ending with bitter. Juicy saliva mouth. Light bodied, served at room temp - very wine like, good amount of tannins . Very nice.

Hazy orange to golden pour, no head. Aroma is of a very smooth and characteristic lambik, some fruits combined with earthy and basement tones. Flavor is quite sour, no carbonation and very smooth. Very nice.

Bottle @ home, tfs Vaiz! Aroma is woody, hay, light brett, wrang.
Flavour is watery fruity sourness, some dust and wood. Nice and smooth.

Bottle at Maltzillas tasting. 2010 vintage. Pours slightly hazy dark golden color with no head. Faint aroma of wood and funkiness. Slightly fruity taste with some wood and almost no sourness. Medium body with no carbonation. Im guessing the flavors and aromas are due to this being so young. I have I bottle Ill hold onto for a while to see how it changes.

Rating from older notes, from Kwintessens 2008 at brewery Cantillon.
Red golden colour, very slight haze, no carbonation, no head. Aroma of honey, lime, wood, some apple and peach, cellar, some distinct tartness, but quite more mellow than expected. Complex and very inviting. Flavour has wheat, lemon and apple, honey and oak. Vanilla and spices. Dry as a bone. Finish dry, some sour notes. Very nice.
(Sample, from bottle, @ the brewery)

According to my sources, this is a rare type of beer. While I appreciate the attempt, and it is a very interesting taste, I can see why they dont generally produce unblended lambics. This has no carbonation, and is very dry. There is practically no sweetness at all, which was surprising but not bad.  It just demands a different expectation and scale for judging. It doesnt even really compare to other beers in my mind.  I like this, but it obviously is not your everyday goto beer.

Poured a slightly hazy orange-yellow with zero head.  Aroma is tart and sour with some lemon and fruit.  Taste has pretty much no carbonation.  Smooth and fruity at first.  Transitions into a tart finish with lemons and yeast.  Slightly watery, could use more flavor.  Very enjoyable overall, a good balance of sweet flavors with the tart yeast notes.
Really lacked any substantial character, perhaps because it was only one year old.  Was a little bit acidic.  Dont even really know what to say, one of the more confusing beers Ive had recently.
Gold pour with a nose of tart fruit and wood. Taste was fruity, but blended well with the wood, alcohol and sour finish.

Bottle shared at the 2nd Annual Sour Town tasting on 4/23/11. Clear amber pour with no head. Aroma of apple juice, funk, malt and vinegar. Sourness in the flavor up front with a bit of maltiness and some apple character before a sour vinegary finish. Not much carbonation at all.
(bottled 2010) Strong sour aroma.  Pours a cloudy orange, thin head. Grassiness, thin palate. Strong tart  finsh. Blue cheese, yeastiness. Satisfying lambic.

Mostly clear orangish amber with no head, kinda viscous... Lemon tart sour bretty aroma, not overly pungent but nicely balanced... Fairly tart, not lively and as such i believe the sourness doesnt quite pop the way it could, some spice, peppery? Medium to medium thin body, wish it had more carbonation...

Served in a Cantillon tulip. 2009 Vintage picked up at Capones.

Pours a moderate orange color with a thin white head and plenty of large bubbles when first poured. Even a hard pour cannot yield much of a head, though I wont really dock an unblended lambic on this point. Nose is moderately funky with some earth and a bit of hay. Theres a bit of lactic character there, but its not overpowering at all.

The flavor follows the nose quite closely. Theres some initial acidity followed by a bit of earth and very light funk. Mouthfeel is light with very low carbonation. Acidity is somewhat brisk but no terribly long-lasting. Drinkability is pretty nice. Had this with plenty of cheese and it served its purpose quite well. Still, not one of the better Cantillon beers Ive had.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-13-2011

Colore arancio lucido senza alcuna schiuma. Aroma di pesca, tagliente, formaggio salato, limone, e legnoso. Medio corpo con un palato ricco, denso, ma ancora soavemente calmo e liscio. Termina con note di cedro, sentori astringenti e legnosi. Tutte le note acidule  in questa birra arrivano nel finale, con un tonfo enorme che si avverte nella mascella. Questa è una lambic impressionante.

750ml bottle. Rating #662. Clear golden pour with no head whatsoever, kind of looks like apple juice. Has a sour apple aroma, very juicy. Very dry and slightly bitter, more sour apple flavor, didnt seem to great to me. (1612)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 75cL bottle from brewery in Brussels. Year 2007 bottled 02.011. Pours a golden honey color. No head or carbonation. Aroma is dominated by sour and sweet (a slight smell of old crusted honey) characters. Feels very smooth (no carbonation) and slightly thick. Taste is a rather mellow sour mixed with an almost honey-like sweetness (though no taste if honey). There is a full sour background, and the beer gets a bit more sour and dry (and less sweet) as I get through the bottle. Overall, not as sour as expected - doesnt have the full intensity sour that other Cantillon  lambics have (like the gueuze). Not sure why that is. Still a good beer though.

Bottle shared at a recent tasting. Beer is yellow and has pretty much no head. There is slight haze.

There is a strong sour aroma -- pretty one note. It smells about what I expected.

Im not sure why I assumed that an unblended lambic would be more funky than the blended guezes but thats not the case at all. This beer is not tart, there is no sulfur character, not a lot of funk. Drinkability is high. I really enjoy this beer but its not what I expected.

Serving type: bottle

750 ml bottle, Bio, brewed in 2003, bottled in 2007. Pours a medium gold, almost no head, some sediment at the last pours. Big, funky, complex, elegant, developed nose, hay, straw, earth, wood, brett, oxidized apples. Bone dry, medium bodied, no CO2, very acidic. Complex, elegant, rather mature, very acidic taste, brett, straw, wheat, earth, ripe apples, dry cider, red currants, cranberries. (2011-01-05)

En lite ovanlig lambic på så sätt att den är unblended, den renaste lambicformen.
Doften är mycket snäll och innehåller tydliga persikatoner. Vätskan är helt utan kolsyre och har en mycket distinkt och trevlig syrlighet som man känner helt ut i örsnibborna.
I eftersmaken kommer det fram syrliga vinteräpplen, persika i fin balans.
Helt underbar

Bottle.

Slightly hazy orange with no head. Soft aroma with light funk, grape, wood and apples. The taste was elegant, not that sour but very, very drinkable. Dry and with a light mouth feel still very good. Almost no carbonation. Refreshing, another bottle please!

750ml bottled poured inappropriately into my new 3 glass. Bottled on October 20, 2010, brewed October 30, 2007...Pours a really dark dark gold with only light carbonation. No real head rises, a few watery bubbles after youre done pouring. No lacing...The aroma is really light, only gives off some musky horse blanket, a little boring...Taste is also pretty light, shows off lots of oak, spider webs, chalk, musky. Not very sour, a little but more bitter than sour if that makes sense. 

Maybe Im just not a fan of unblended beers, or this wasnt a great batch. Either way, this is the probably the least good Cantillon Ive had and cant imagine having this again.

Bottle, 2004 vintage, thx OldSock. Pours a hazy yellow/green color with virtually no head. Aroma is sharp funk, lemon/lime, wood. Flavor is sharp tartness with a carbonated lemonade finish. Acidic but not unplesant. If you let one of these age for 10 years, I hope youre ready for tart beer.

Bottle @ home. Tangerine orange appearance with no head. Slightly sour, wild, lightly woody,  Belgian ale aroma. Slight citrusy, smooth sour, wild, barnyard lambic flavor. Tart finish. Very smooth and non-abrasive lambic.

Thanks to Chalsk.  Pours a darker gold with faint carbonation which leads to. A tiny head that quickly dissipated.  Aroma is tart citrus and barnyard funk.  Taste is tart with a nice mellowing bitterness on the finish.  Excellent.

Pours an golden orange color with little to no head.  Has an funky, sweet aroma.  Has some characteristics of apple juice.  Has a tarty taste with some earthiness from the yeast.  Very tasty and supprisingly smooth on the back end.

750 ml green bottle.Vintage 2007. A honey gold beer and basically totally flat. The aroma is slightly funky, sweet and like apple juice. The taste is slightly tart, apple juice, wood and the palate is flat and almost watery like. It was like someone poured water with apple juice and mixed in some oak chips. I have to say I love Cantillon but this is my least favorite from them so far.

very white wine flavoured and dry.
should probably be a little cooler than room temperature
thin bodied and unusually flat.
only slightly tart
very dry and oaky.
i like it. very uniuqe

750ml green corked and capped bottle.

It pours a clear orange with no head, just a bit of soapy bubbles that quickly pop. Great for a non-carbonated beer.

The smell is nothing but classic. It isnt as funky as other wild ales, but it is nice and tart with a huge lemony zestiness. There is a suprising amount of sweetness as well. The oak meshes it all together with a smooth vanilla like scent.

The flavor is very nice. It is a bit vinegary at first but it mellows out nicly. It isnt overly sour but there is a nice mouthpuckering sensation with the first few sips. The oak comes in with a nice woody note. There is a hint of spiciness to go along with the sourness and a slightly funky aftertaste. The oak is surprising here, it really shines with the lambic flavors.

I have only had 2 uncarbonated lambics, and this one is definitely the crown of the style. You somehow forget the carbonation, I think the acidity of it has to do something with that.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-01-2011 07:14:30

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2017 Re-rate, March 2018: as I had noted in my original review, this was one I wanted to come back to, it just took a little longer than expected. 75cl bottle picked up at the brewery shop. It pours a clean golden color, completely flat with no head. Aroma is dry and lemony, full of barnyard funk and hay, with some acidic white wine vinegar notes in the finish. Taste is also mega dry and funky, with notes of basement dust, hay, light cheese and a white wine vinegar-like tartness. The finish is dry and softly bitter, like boiled hops bitterness. Medium body with no carbonation. Overall, quite good complexity for a lambic, will see how this evolves over time.
Original review, March 2011: 375ml bottle. Pours a cloudy orangish color. No head to speak of. Aroma is signature Cantillons, only some orders of magnitude less intense. Same applies to taste. The body in this beer is comparable to still water. No carbonation at all. Given others ratings I guess I got a wrong batch: flat body is not the problem actually, its the flatness in flavors which set this apart from all other Cantillons Ive had so far. Strange. Positive note: this means Ill have to come back to this one soon. Score 2.8

Cask @ Moeder Lambic, anno 2007.
Dorée, léger trouble, mousse blanche.
Arôme de choux, cave, bois de chêne avec qcq notes citronnées.
Une lambic qui est vraiment à maturation allant sur ses 4ans.
En bouche, une lambic dexception, note de fruits qui me rappelle le raisin blanc, sureau et cet aspect mûrit se ressent vraiment bien au palais pour un fini sec et une carbonation minimale avec des saveurs de bois, cave. Le mieux est de la gouter.
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2011 bottle.  pours flat orange amber.   aroma of funky, earthy leather, light plastic.  pretty acidic.   good.  drinkable.  dry.   complex.   rustic.  great.

2008 bottling. Breathtaking. A bit boring to look at when poured out, it looks like a slightly hazy golden colour, very little head to speak of. When you breathe in the aroma, it is thick and rich, lots of barnyard sour smells and yeast. Taste is moderately sour, and extremely funky, lingering aftertaste, smooth palate... I took an hour to drink this just because I couldnt bear the idea of not having any left!

Bottle generously shared by Sparky27...thanks Eric!!!  Cloudy, straw colored brew with meerly a whisp of a white head.  Lots of cheesy, horse-blankety funk in this one.  Get some grapes and citrus pith as well.  Really no carbonation to speak of...flat as a pancake.  Interesting that although I enjoy sours/lambics, I havent enjoyed most Cantillons.  This is no exception.

Bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. An unblended lambic for sale in a bar in Norway! Times they are-a-changing indeed... :-) Pours a near-headless clear, deep golden body. Nose is brettanomyces , barnyard funk, hints of tobacco and  acidic tones. Taste follows with more of the same, plus some tart, near-citric notes of apple, hay and green grapes. Mouthfeel is smooth and nearly devoid of carbonation. Incredibly tasty lambic that goes down too fast, leaving me wanting more. Lammmmmbic.

750ml.  Pours hazy gold with a thin white head.  The nose is light horse blanket and sour grapes.  The taste is funk, aspirin, lemon and dank fruit.  Nearly flat mouthfeel.  Good lambic.  Not as good as I thought it would be but still nice.

Bottle pours yellow with a tint of green and almost no head.  Aroma shows notes of acidic grapefruit, green apple, and funk.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of oak, and salted lemons.  Overall body is moderate with moderate to heavy acidity.

Pours crystal clear gold with absolutely no head. aroma is huge barnyard cheesy funk with herbal, and oak notes. Body is thin, and watery. flavor is intensely sour, dominating anything else. I really liked this. If you like mouth-puckering sour, this is it.

2007 bio version, 75cl bottle from P&M Getränke, Bonn. Pours light golden with no head at all. No carbonation whatsoever manifests in this beer. Sour aroma (quelle surprise). Slightly funky citrus flavour. Flawed.
375ml bottle courtesy of Mike).  Pours hazy yellow with slight white head.  Aroma of grape, fruit and funk.  Taste is sour with a salty note.  Nice.
gold blond coloured body with a little white head a fruity sour aroma a fruity sweet sour taste with a sweet sour bitter finish
Clear goldblond coloured beer with no head and no carbonation. Sour aroma. Medium palate. Finish is slightly sour ending rather dry. Lambic one. Not really my kind of beer.

Bottlle from Beer Ritz, Leeds. Light golden pour with a minimal and fast fading white head. Nose was plenty of green apple, citrus, barnyard, vinegar and a hint of barrel. Very dry flavour with more juicy fruitiness, and notes of yeast and grass. Delicate and soft, the sourness was in no way overpowering, with real complexity simmering away in the palate.
