Fresh, clean and dry finish. Have to try an older bottle of this as Im sure this score would move on up aplenty. First class lambic.
759 bottle thanks to the desert fox.  Classic cantillon.  Light head.  Nice golden color.  Sour.
75cl bottle at Johnnys Off License. As well as most of the Lambic beers, no head and a little bit amber. Iron, not too much sharp. Very appreciable. Taste of plum and lemon.

Drinking this out of a flute!  Pours a nice pale golden color with some bubbles in it.  Smells of sugar and some souring grapes.  Fairly sour taste.  Not very sweet at all likes the aroma might suggest.  I like this sour taste however.
Bottle from 2007. Clear golden with no head. Flavour is malt, wheat, sour, tart, barnyard, funk, fruit and hops.

750ml bottle (2006) from La Cave à Bulles in Paris 
Appearance: Clear golden with a light ring around the edges and no lacing 
Aroma: Fresh tart fruits and barnyard 
Taste: Tart fruits, barnyard, lemons and acidic 
Nice. This is my last rate of 2010. Going to toast the new year with this great lambic.

shared bottle.  pours a deep golden color with little to no head.  big funky nose with lots of barnyard notes and light citrus.  very tart mouthfeel with big lemon sourness up front and a dryer back end.  very acidic throughout.  more big dusty barnyard flavors over the mouth.  huge dryness on the back with more barnyard and citrus notes.

Pours a clear copper color with no head. The aroma is strong of barnyard, oak, lemon, and has a sweetish edge to it. The flavor is tart and funky with oak, leather, sweat socks, vanilla, lemon, and  horseblanket. No carbonation at all, but still very complex and has a nice mouthfeel with a citrus rind finish. A really nice lambic.

750 ml Bottle. 2010 Vintage. Courtesy of peteinSD.  Orange pour with no head.  The nose was definitely the most unique thing about this beer.  We kicked around a few adjectives trying to describe it and I believe used gym towel, B.O. and stale dishrag were among the most common.  Seriously lots of odd stale and musty notes in the aroma.  The flavor was mildly funky with some strong cheese notes and a slight bit of lemongrass.  Absolutely no carbonation which made the beer taste a little too watery.  Overall it was ok, but not on par with Cantillons other offerings.

8 year old bottle.
i dont really have the vocabulary to describe lambic, but this is very "lambic". its face-puckering crazy funky sour, but has a lot of earthy complexity underneath.

Bottle: Poured a clear golden color lambic with no bubble or any carbonation as unblended lambic should be. Aroma of funk and barnyard notes are quite dominant with some stinking cheese notes also noticeable. Taste is also dominated by funk with loads of barnyard note. Body is about average. Not bad though not my favourite  I think a classic gueuze is still better then this.

750ml bottle @ Patricks. Hazy orange body with no head. Nice, mild acidic and funky aroma with grapefruit and oranges. The flavor is tart and fruity, but not really sour as expected. There is surprisingly much fruit in the flavor, particular oranges. The flavor is almost orange juice sweet, but still quite tart. Moderate funky and some malt. Much more matured than jonge lambic and still a fresh fruity flavor, this was a big surprise. Very nice, but I still never figured it out, need to try it again.

Bottle thanks to Beer 2000 .Pours gplden with a small white head.Aroma is funky, cellar ,oak and lemon .Flavor os sour and funky with a lot of tannins and malt.Thin to medium body,dry sour finish .Very nice lambic

Thanks to Dstructo for  sharing this one with me. Very fruity and tart, but  what really struck me was the burning sensation I got from this. It felt fruity and tart at first but then I got this burning, acid like sensation on the way down. It was like a warming sensation in my stomach, I loved it.

Bottle split with Pat and Vinny, courtesy of Vin. Pours a bright hazy orange body with absolutely no head or lacing. Aroma is leather penny loafers and tart. Mouthfeel is extremely smooth, no carbonation whatsoever, with great notes of tart and sour fruit in the finish. Awesome unblended lambic.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with Vin and James. Pours a reflective, shiny grapefruit orange with absolutely no head. Aroma of peach, barnyard funk, sharp, savory cheese, lemon, and oak. Fuller medium body with a rich, thick, yet still suavely calm and smooth palate. Finishes with cedary, astringent woody notes. All the sour in this brew comes in the back, with a huge wallop that one can sense in the jaw. This is an awesome lambic. Fantastic.

Bottle/750ml - Poured a very still copper-orange in color with a very thin head and almost no carbonation.  Aroma is quite barnyard "funky"... ripe cheddar, light fruits (apple, pear) and the acetic of apple cider vinegar.  Flavor is also funky with plenty of apples, strong cheese and other fruity esters.  Finish is slightly sour and clean... really good sour beer... I am honored!

Bottle.  Pour is still, hazy, copper with no head.  Aroma is old sock, lactic acid, cherries, lightly floral, and barnyard.  Flavor is also funky with light acetic acid notes and hints of barnyard, berries, and lightly floral in the finish.  As expected and quite good.
Hazy pale gold with zero head. Lovely aroma of light funk and lemon. Lemon on the flavor, lightly sour, with subdued wood characteristics and low carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy deep orange amber. As expected no head. Big sour aromas with plenty of lemons and green apples. Some vinegar acidity and little earthy funk. Good stuff. Flavours are quite acidid and sour. Finish is very dry. Great beer.
750mL into tulip. Never thought I would see the day that I had to drain-pour a Cantillon. This beer was as flat as a board. Terrible beer, worst Cantillon I have experienced. Was expecting much more!
750 corked bottle from Sanford. No carbonation. Orange body. Taste is apples and a bit of vinegar. Very dry. Nice.

Pours straw colored. Still with no head. The aroma is quite oniony. Vinegar, straw, strawberries, sweaty sock, horse blanket and straw. The flavor is quite tart. Onion, sock, straw, berries, horse blanket, and vinegar. Really nice.

Bottle, purchased at The HopCat. Pours hazy amber/gold, no head, no lacing. Nose is sweaty, horsey, tight, rank, acid. Some funky apples here too, plus cheddar, cider, vinegar, almost salty. Mmmmmm... This is super-flavourful, with loads of soft cider and sweat and funk with a very fresh and bracing acidity, some real cheesiness in the palate. Lovely.

750 ml bottle unfortunately shared by me during the jimmack 2010 invitational. Man was this the dog of the day. Thin flat lifeless body. Ugly flat lifeless hazy orange body. Aroma was weak and the flavor was bad. Notes of vomit and funk along with ahint of sawdust and burnt rubber. Ugh....total dog.

As Grand Cru Bruocsella Lambic Bio 2006, bottled aug 2009.
tasted sep 2010.
cloudy orange, no head 2
very nice mild sour aroma, flowery, fresh, aroma notes blend in well together, pretty well rounded aroma..
flavor is liekly well composed, well balanced. Sourish of course, but mild and flowery. Very refreshing, very nice flavor. amazing how soft and "clean" it is in the flavor, how complex yet simple. Im not the greatest cantillon fan, but this one is in my opinion one of the best of theirs ive tasted. Almost no off flavors or strange stuff going on.. impressive.  Intended to score it 7 on aroma, but it so deserves 4+ so i give it 8.

2006, bottled 09. Bio version. Slightly hazy gold, no head. Aroma of apples and musty basements. Tastes very fruity with ripe and tart apples, grapefruit and peaches. Quite woody. The sourness is pretty reserved but is deep and lingers. Certainly feels alive in the mouth despite the lack of bubbles. More approachable than expected and perhaps needs more time, but lovely enough now.

Yellow - orange coloured beer with almost no head. Perfectly balanced mellow geueze aroma.Flavour starts off very smoot with a nice dry sour finish. Another good one from cantillon. (Corked Bottle 75cl)

(750 ml bottle. Rated @ 21.5.2010.)
Hazy orange colour, no head. The aroma is lovely lemon tart, citric acid bursting into the nose. Not as brutally sour as Iris. The taste is a nice mixture of grapefruit, lemons and oak. Tart mouthfeel, no carbonation and  a nicely dry finish. Great brew from Cantillon yet again.

Green bottle, 75 cl, 2006, bottled in 2008, better before 12 2020, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on September 4 2010; eye: peach, lightly hazy, no effervescence, no head, no lacing; nose: sourness, horse, farm, old, woody, acidity; mouth: sourness, horse, farm, old, woody, finale in woody-farm with presence of sourness, full body, not much carbonation, quite sour and acidic, a bit thin; overall: not for me

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille verte, 75 cl, 2006, embouteillée en 2008, meilleure avant 12 2020, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 4 septembre 2010; il : pêche, légèrement voilée, pas deffervescence, pas de mousse, pas de dentelle; nez : aigreur, cheval, ferme, « vieux », boisé, acidité; bouche : aigreur, cheval, ferme, « vieux », boisé, finale en boisé-ferme avec présence daigreur, corsé, très peu carbonatée, très aigre et acide, texture un peu mince; en résumé : pas pour moi

(bottle - corked & capped 750 ml) Peach colored pour with very little head, mainly from the pouring. No carbonation whatsoever. Sour and earthy aroma with a very strong apple cider and vinegar hint. Flavor is very tart and sour at the start with a strong cider-like note to it. Lots of earthy tart flavors coming through at the end and lingering for a while. The lack of carbonation kind of threw me for a loop, but the flavor is fantastic.

Corked bottle.Pours an average cheddar orange with an aroma of thin sour, rotten velvety cedar plank.  Hints of old cheese and old orange rind in there too.  Flavor is thin and weak cedar vegetable.  Thats the best I can describe it.  Mouthfeel is average.  Not my favorite Cantillon.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Pours hazy orange with no head, bottle from 07. Aroma is nice lemon tart, oak, and acidic. Taste is citrus up front, nice dry oak, and finishing tart and funky. Nice brew, not as good as their others but cantillon never fails.

Served at "cellar temperature" as noted on the bottle. Looks just like apple juice. No head and very minimal carbonation. The aroma is quite harsh, almost like an old shoe. However the flavor is quite surprising. Not as bad as I thought it would be. Complex flavor. Tart, but quite drinkable with a dry finish. Better than a white wine. Worth a try if you can find it.

Bottled in 2009. Shared by chswimmer on BA. Thanks, Craig.

A still life: ambrosial funk, white wine grapes, fresh lumber, and citric exocarp. Yellow and immobile in the glass. Slim in body, but not thin.

An eminently drinkable lambic.
user_location: The Court of the Crimson King, California, USA

text: Bottle - Probably shouldnt have had this after trying the kriek and framboise Lou Pepes earlier in the night, but here goes. Pours straw yellow with a very small white head. Not much of a smell--actually a little honey sweetness and tartness. Taste is yeasty funkiness, with some tart lemon and orange rind. Sour, but not over the top. I think this would be great for someone starting out in lambics, as it the sour notes and funkiness are not super-pronounced and potentially offensive. Its well-carbonated and medium-bodied. Pleasant, but not a standout.

A: The pour is a golden/yellow straw color with maybe a kiss of orange. No head at all.

S: The nose is quite grassy and "green", if you will. Some lemons, green apples, and a definite earth. Not the most aggressive of the Cantillons in terms of nose.

T: The flavor is a bit bland as well. Fairly earthy, some mild mustiness, and grapefruit, lemons, and oak pretty much make up the flavor.

M: The body is medium with a slick feel on the tongue due to the relative lack of carbonation.

D: Probably the most lackluster of all the Cantillon lambics Ive had. Not much depth of flavor, but perhaps I need to try an aged bottle of this.

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho.
maybe my least favorite of the cantillon sours, nice hitns of tannins and wine grape.

4th March 2010. Slighty hazy gold beer. Some sourness and wood in the nose. Palate is a bit dry. Sour - of course - a little lemony but tempered by some softness. Enough sourness to make you salivate not a pucker job. Easy drinking lambic.

75cl Bottle, shared by a friend, thanks Harmen! Clear orange colour, no head. Aroma of light sourness, wheat, funk, sweet fruit, light woody, cant really pinpoint it but its really nice. Flavour is sweet, fruity, wheat, turns sour and a bit vinegary later on. Sour finish. Not as sour as I expected, still too much for me, and the lack of carbonation puts me off as well. Light to medium bodied.
Love the Bruegel on the label.  Rather a tasty lambic.  Tart and a refreshing summer beer.  Oak. Complex.  Serving: Bottle
Bottle from 2007.Orange colour with no head.Aroma is mild sour and slight more watery then other Lambic.Taste of apples and vinagar,flavor of wood and dry wine.
2007 bottle. poured orange with no head. barnyard aroma. flavor was mild tart. hints of rosewater. lingering tart finish. the mouthfeel is thin but smooth. very nice a smooth finish

Bottled November 16, 2009. The beer pours a clear orange color with a small white head. The aroma is awesome with very tart lemons as well as some oak notes. The flavor is pretty good, but not near as tart or sour as the aroma led me to believe it would be. I get notes of lemons with some oak. The beer is extremely dry. The only real problem I have with the beer is that the body is extremely thin and watery. The carbonation is very low.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2016 Pours apricot color in the glass. Nose is slight rind and lemon zest. Taste is sweet tart and slight vinegar. 2010 3.4

2004 vintage - beautiful funky lemon rind and tart old wood. 4.3

Bottled 16 November 2009 -
Pours a clear straw/amber color with no carbonation. As still as wine. A sour earthy tone with subtle hints of wood. A little bit of a spoiled fruit aroma, although I cant place what fruit. Definitely some green apple, but not the dominant aroma. Very tart. A little residual sweetness, though it does not come through very well. You can barely tell it is there, as it is overpowered by the sourness. Thin and sour. Coats the mouth much like vinegar and leaves the tongue feeling like drinking vinegar. But much better than drinking vinegar, of course. The tart sourness does not linger too long, and you can forget about it until you take another sip. Very drinkable. Very refreshing after a long day of brewing. Nice drink to unwind with.

Bottle, 2005 vintage. Orange, very hazy pour, with minimum white head. Some lacing. Aroma of apple tart, citrus, orange, yeast, grapes, a little cherry and some oak. Taste of oak, cherry, fruits, flowers, very sour apple tart, some bitterness as well as vinegary sourness. Big body, lively carbonation, long duration, low viscosity. Refreshing, pleasant and interesting.

Bottle, 75 cl, 2005 vintage. Hazy amber pour with no head. Aroma is really tart (especially right after a Speedway Stout), tart grapes, oak and tart apple. Taste is very tart, tart apples, grapefruit, vinegar. Quite good.

750ml bottle, I think it was bottled in 2007.  Pours medium orange, almost no head, but little bubbles throughout and a fine white ring on top.  Nose is very Cantillon, sour citrus fruits, dried herbs, really sour and funky.  Light carbonation in the mouth.  Classic Cantillon expression, big, funky, barnyard.  Lemon and dried sage, dried mint.  Of course really sour and dry, not as effervescent as the Gueuze.  Pretty refined and nuanced.

0,5 l bottle from CrackedKettle, courtesy of Balazs, thx a lot;-)
Poured clear golden with a light reddish tone, some froathy white head that went away fast. Fruity aroma with melon, peach and green apple, grape. Mild spicy character with vanilla, vinous notes. Tart flavor with oak and tannins, fruity, vinous tastes with must and grape. Herbal and tart aftertaste with salty notes. Classic one.
Poured clear, peach color with no head. Green apple, tart, vinous, acidic aroma. Salty and sour taste. Medium dense, flat body. Simple, but elegant and pure.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2010 (Old BA rate - bottle - thanks Joe for sharing)
Hazy orange-yellow color; poured with a thin white head. Yeasty; funky; a bit bretty...nice stuff here. Cirtic and tart funkiness; bit dry. Smooth and lightish. Very good; tasty; funky and fun.  

Re-rate, June 6 2010, bottle: completely still and tried to get some head, but really difficult with no carbonation.  Really light cheese aroma, some funk, bit of earth.  Sourish on top of the funkiness for the taste, but very muted compared to the last sampling.  Thin, completely still body. Could just be me, but definitely not all that adventurous.   6, 4, 6, 4, 14

Bottle from Drink of Fulham. Golden-orange pour with no head. Aromas of pineapple, barnyard funkiness,green apples, a little sweetness. Flavours of lemon peel, lemon zest, lime, some salt, grapefruit. Crisp sour flavours. Zesty lemon tang on the palate. Excellent lambic.
bottle pours orange with a bright white head.  Aroma is fruity citrus and hay with light funk.  Flavor is sour grapefruit and lime with a smooth sourness that isnt vinegary or off putting.
just one of my favorites cantillon, i dont understand how it is possible that no one has yet reviewed on ratebeer.

[bottle purchased at brewery]
Complex aroma of sweet strawberries, pineapple, malt, pickles, and promise of some woody bitterness. Hazy orange with only a partial ring of large bubbles--not a looker. Flavour is also complex--more so than the usual Lambic offering: almost mouth-puckering sourness and woody bitterness begin and then very quickly develop into a pleasant fruity blend that includes strawberries, pineapple, mango, and lotus root. The sourness leaves after a minute, giving a clean finish. Light body, low carbonation.

Bottled 75cl. It pours a hazy orange beer with no head. (hardly any bubbles). Absolutely fantastic aroma of, here we go: Brett, horse blanket, mango, burnt match, papaya, fleurs de sel, wild strawberries, oak, lemon peel, a lot of lavender and rosemary, clotted cream, jarred pickles, candied apricot, faint mint, cork, grapefruit, gooseberries and melon de Bourgogne show up in the nose which is extremely inviting. Strong sourness in the taste. Wonderful brett components. No carbonation. This beers makes you cringe- lovely. Mindblowingly delicious, unique and complex. One bad thing about this beer in my opinion:  The fact the bottle was empty after spending a wonderful time reveling in every sip made me sad. Thanks Toni for providing me with this beer :-)
Pours lightly hazy golden with no head. Aroma is sour with notes of fruit and wood. Flavor is sweet, tart, wood, acidic lemon. Earthy dry finish.

A classic Cantillon. Great appearance. Tart, lemon, acidic nature and a lovely caramel body. Hay, floral hops and earthy yeast. I get a mild sense of butterscotch too. Really easy going on the pallet more so than other lambics. This is one fine beverage. Great for the summer. I love this work of art. This art form should never cease......Cheers Phil L for another stunner from the Beermerchants via Cantillon direct.

Bottle thanks to dchmela, I think.  Ive been sitting on it for a little while, though its not an older bottle.  Pours still as can be, with only a few bubbles from the pour.  Dark gold, slightly orange and pretty much clear.  Sour oak and more tropical than citrus notes... mangoes and peaches.  Very thin, really, both in the taste and the palate.  One-dimensional, but its unblended, so what do I expect?  Decent, but not my favorite Cantillon by any means.

Bottle. Still golden with no head. Next to no carbonation. Aroma of funk, hay, summer fruit, lemon and earth. The flavour is more of that wild funky character with zesty fruit and oak. Tart in the mouthfeel but in true Cantillon fashion the drinkability is superb. A gorgeous beer on all levels. Wow! Cheers Ian for sharing!
Golden with a white head. Really sour aroma with notes of dust. Really sour and surprisingly bitter.
Had at RBWG 2010... not sure who it was from.  Straight up malty Belgian. Good stuff here.  Lovely yeast aromatics going on.

I enjoyed this brew very much! The lack of carbonation felt strange at first, but the flavors that came out when it warmed up a bit more than made up for that. The nose is very specific; I bet I could single this out as a Cantillon brew at a blind tasting by the aroma alone! Taste contains a lot of of apples, green currant-berries, oak, yeast and the specific cantillon-taste that resembles blue cheese, hay and something else... Very complex, but not overly sour, unlike some other lambics from cantillon.

Bottle. 

Pours an almost glowing deep amber with some disparate airy bubbles that quickly disappears. 

The aroma is musty and earthy with notes of overripe apples and pears, lemon, leafs and Cantillons house character of funky barnyard, mud and hay. 

The flavor is medium sweet and lightly sour. Lots of aromas of overripe apples and pears. Tart lemon notes lead the way to a funky middle of mud, barnyard and leafs. A surprisingly noticeable bitterness goes well with a tightening tartness in the finish. Ends with tart lemon notes and mineral notes. 

Medium body and basically without carbonation, which makes it appear as having a bigger body than most beers from Cantillon. Not very dry either. 

Good stuff. When served in a Cantillon traditional gueuze glass, it is hard to imagine anything more rustic.

Bouteille 750ml (bio 2006), courtoisie de JulienHuxley. De couleur dorée-orange et semi-voilée. Nez de levures fruitées sauvages aigres (pommes vertes cidreuses, petits fruits sûrs,  raisins verts, petites notes de citron) et aux petites notes terreuses ainsi que des notes herbeuses (herbes fraîches et mouillées) et légèrement boisé (fût de chêne),. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement nul et une texture sirupeuse fruitée. Goût de levures sauvages fruitées moyennement aigres (pommes vertes aux notes cidreuses, léger de raisins verts, notes de petits fruits sûrs, traces de lime) aux notes terreuses lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute de faibles notes de fromage vieilli avec de faibles traces de beurre puis en finale lon retrouve un léger goût boisé de fût de chêne acccompagné dun léger goût herbeux (herbes mouillées) ainsi quun regain daigreur fruitée légèrement asséchante et quelques traces de poivre très doux. Post-goût moyen-long et un peu sec, moyen-aigre de levures fruitées (pelures de pommes, léger moût de raisins verts et traces de zest dagrumes) avec de faibles notes boisées.

750ml bottle.  Very little carbonation, pours a thick yellowish amber with very little head.  Smells like a pile of fall leaves, with grass, hay, barnyard, and a touch of sour.  Flavor is not too sour, but pleasantly earthy, grassy, and woody.  Fades cleanly into a pleasant citrus peel finish.

Sample from a 0.75L bottle, enjoyed@Håndverkerstuene, Oslo.  A layer of tiny offwhite bubbles, over a light amber colored body with good clarity. Rounded citrus-fruity aroma, with a light tartness and notes of freshly cut wood, earth and unripe berries. Taste is acidic and fruity; citrus, cider-apples and berries. Also some rounded woodden notes, with a hint of sweetness down below. Very soft in the mouth, due to the low carbonation level. Finishes dry and tart fruity. Very nice, indeed.

Bottle. A small white head settles on a sparkly pale golden body. Aroma is packed with funk, mostly cheese like, with notes of wood, sawdust, berries, apples, and citric acidity. More tart than sour, definitely reminds me of the same tartness as you find in cranberries. Ends massively dry. Light bodied, this lambic is less carbonated than others Ive had, making it a bit more mellow in the mouth. Drinkable, refreshing and rough at the same time. Loved it.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2011 750mL Belgium label courtesy of Travlr. Pours a flat, clear, light orange. No head. Aroma is a bit horsey with leather saddle, some acidic white wine, Brett. Tastes is like strawberry tart plus red apple skins, lemon, lime, leather. Later Im tasting some buttery bourbon goodness coming out of the complexity and more barrel character. Really sour, smooth, wet, tannic with lots of lacto in the finish. Light on the palate. Watery, leathery texture. Truly awesome. 2/24/2010 7/4/8/5/16=4.0750mL 2004 ed US label thanks to TheMadFermentationist aka OldSock. Flat yellow pour creates a massive funky nose: sweaty, lemon, grapefruit, fresh citrus, white vinegar. Lots of impending sourness. The overall body to me is not very sour- more tannic like some really good lemon tea. Yup, like some really good lemon tea. Its good stuff, but nowhere near the level of Iris. 3/27/2011 8/4/7/4/15=3.8

Lambic Bio - 2006 vintage. Pours hazy golden, no head. Very light carbonation. Aroma is all bretty horseblanket, flavour is super sour, like sucking on a lime. Pretty cool. Very interesting but very hard going.

Had the Cantillon Bruocsella 2002 Grand Cru. Orange colored brew. Aroma is a bit sour, grainy. Flavor is vinous like white wine, sourness, green apples, some cherry. Drinkable, but I dont want it all night.

Grapes, some green apples, vinegar.  Theres a solid funkiness from whatever bacteria live in the Cantillon brewery. This was my first Cantillon and so I was girded for some mouth-puckering sourness. Unfortunately for me, this version is of a relatively mild sourness for a tart Belgian. I mean, it has a strong vinegar note and citric tartness, but it didnt quite knock my socks off, like I was hoping for. It has certain qualities comparable to an unflavored kombucha. Flat. Drinkable out of interest in the different and odd but a bit disappointing really. I could see it becoming an acquired taste if I had easier access.

In the bottle from Beertopia. My first unblended lambic and completion of all the styles. Not sure why it took me so long to have this style. I think it is better than flemmish sour, but not as good as blended lambics. Pours a dark yellow brownish ochre color. Very thin to no head. The aroma is very sour and barnyard wet horse blanket. Moldy. Brett tartness prevails, but the apple cider similarities indeed emerge. Although there is something a bit different from a typical tart cider- moldy hay perhaps? This is indeed different. Im not sure that I ever need another one.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2014 04 Vintage Bottle. Orange golden pour with some minuscule head. Easier to pucker wise than all previous cantillons, although i do like their tart brews. Could sniff this for a while.

Re rate, another 04 bottle. Have gained a bit of appreciation for this style.

Bottle. The aroma is sour,light dry and with a light smell of leather. The beer has no head and the body is clear and red. The taste is light dry and sour, not bitter. The first sip tasted a little bit like toothpaste, but not in a bad way. The body is dry without carbonation and rather light. A good one.

Bottled 750ml. -from Beer Planet, 9.50. Cloudy orange/golden coloured, no head at all, usual tart Cantillon nose. Slight acidic and very tart with notes of wood and fruits. Quite interesting and rather soft spicy finish. Refreshing, but to be honest expected more.

First unblended lambic!  This is the final style I need to try as listed on RateBeer, so I guess Ill just stop drinking beer now.  Just kidding, that will never happen.  Bought it at the Cantillon Brewery in Brussels and shared it at a BeerAdvocate tasting. Brewed in 2006 and bottled in 2009.

Clear golden color, mostly still, but some large bubbles form after an aggressive pour. Looks almost like a cask ale in a way. Some lacing is present as the beer is swirled around in the glass.

Aroma is tart, funky, and bretty. Green apples and other light fruit notes as well as wood are noticeable.

Flavor is bretty and woody with some funk. Some apple juice notes. Very tasty beer with a hint of sweetness to balance the sourness.

The beer is pretty flat, as intended, and this works very well. Really dont miss the carbonation on this one. Dry and sour on the palate with tartness lasting.

Drinkability is high. I could down this much more easily than your typical sour beer.

2006, bottled in 2009 courtesy of ogivlado who brought it from Belgium and shared with me.  Poured a quite hazy orange-golden body with a tiny white head that went away immdediately. Subdued funky tart aroma, some sweet maltiness. The mouthfeel is remarkably soft at the beginning and cushions the acidic assault that comes just a little later, funky, ends spicy/peppery. I liked it, not the best Lambic Ive had but certainly interesting.

Gold pour.  No head.  Funky and fruity aroma.  Some lemon, dank basement and wet wood.  This bottle was quite flat.  Had a woody flavor with a little fruit and a lot of funk.  My least favorite Cantillon to date.
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2009 75 cl Bottle. Pours a nice gold color with no head. Wet hay, apples, oak and lemony aroma. Calvados kind of flavor; apple and wood. Great balance, soft lambic.

Golden pour with a beautiful suspended carbonation. Tons on tiny bubbles slowly make their way to the top. Aroma is massively funky with very pronounced nectar fruits, lemon, citrus, slight oak, straw, and hay. Flavor is very acidic, rude, and tart. Acidic lemon, grapefruit, orange, and oaken cider. Palate is very slippery and almost wholly un-carbonated. Rude, lacerative, and delicious.

Dark gold pour with zero head, and some suspended carbonation- really cool how slowly they rise to the surface. Aroma is incredibly funky, with tons of brett, along with notes of red wine vinegar, lemon zest, and some slight oak. Also some hay, and perhaps even a bit of spruce. Flavor starts slow, then wallops the tongue with brett, cider vinegar, acidic lemon and grapefruit, and a bit of barnyard. Palate is very low on carbonation, but crescendos into an aggressively acidic wash over the tongue. I really like this lambic.
Hazy yellow color with no head.  Kind of flat.  Sour aroma of vinegar, yeast, and oak.  Flavor has yeast, oak, lemon, and oak. Tart and sour.

Bottled	St Albans BF 09.  Thanks to harrisoni for this.  A golden coloured lambic with a super funky welcoming aroma .  It is the type of smell that you can taste and it wafts you in.  The taste is acidic and grapey.  Good sourness yet never overtly challenging.  A pretty easy drinking lambic.
Orange coloured and hazy, has a white head, fully diminishing. Aroma: Sulfur, acid, oak. Flavor: Heavy, harsh acidic, and faint fruit. Acid, dry texture.
Bottle at Stone Sourfest 09. Hazy golden pour. Aroma is tart and sour. Flavor is band aid, tart, plastic, and lemon zest.
Bottle from Hopduvel Gent, fantastic wine-like nose, sourness not aggressive, but fine and elegant, smokey touch, wood ageing nicely blended in, top geuze!!

Bottle from Dranken Geers. Hazy orange amber with no head. Can taste the cask aging, spice, fruits. Has a wine like sourness. And smells of minge. Finish is a little bitter with a hint of wood and smoke.

750ml from State Line. 2007 bottle. Deep orange/amber pour with almost zero carbonation, only a few big bubbles like detergent poured in water. The straight stuff, as you can tell from the nose, which is sharp, musty, and ripe with brett. The mouthfeel is medium, with a moderately dry finish (well, moderate for a Cantillon). Flavor isnt quite as complex as one would like. Plenty sour, with an emphasis on fresh grapefruit and wood, but you dont get the depth of a gueuze. Still pretty rockin but not top drawer.

Bottle. Thanks for sharing this one ChristianScheffel. Pours golden coloured with almost no head. Very funky aroma with notes of musty cellar, citrus, wood and vinegar. Flavours of honey, balsamic vinegar, spice, wood and lemons.

I had this beer on tap at Beachwood BBQs sour beer fest. 
This pours an opaque golden color.  Theres plenty of funk (barnyard, horse blanket etc) to go around.

Pours a hazy dark golden orange color with golden yellow hues when held to a light source and an almost non existent thin bubbly head that dissapears immediately.

Vinegary earthy oak aroma with lots of lactic horse blanket funk. Subtle light fruit notes compliment the strong earthy oak notes.

Medium slightly puckering body that isnt too acidic. Nice tart lactic barnyard horseblanket funk. Light and fairly easy drinking with not as much of a puckering tart mouthfell than I expected or wanted. Dry finish.

Light crisp fruit notes. Cherry, grape, apple pear, etc. Sour lactic funky. Not nearly tart enough but still puckering without being very acidic. More vinegary than anything else with a lot of oak/vanilla.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2012 Cloudy orange with a small white head. Strong funky aroma with barnyard, wood, grapefruit, pineapple, mint, leather and dusty cellar. Tart flavour of wood, leather and grapefruit, with some fruity sweetness and apple notes. Some carbonation would clearly have brought out the flavour a little more
Golden orange colour, no head. Acidic aroma. Extremely sour taste: you can almost feel your teeth dissolving away. On the more delightful side of the lambics.

Organic Lambic pours very flat almost wine like. First sip and it feesl like the sour is on the tip of your tongue.  The acidity is low which makes this the most drinkable Cantillon I have ever had. Very Quaffable.  I plan on aging the other bottle I have.
Sour, no carbonation, no head, oily, flat, acidic, lemony.  Hazy pour, spoiled white wine.  Not my favorite Cantillon.

Sampled form bomber at Wurstkuche tasting.  Pours dark gold with almost zero head.  Aroma has a bunch of funk, mixed in with a cedar-like wood aromas, and some acidity.  Palate is near flat, with a slightly "fatty" mouthfeel that moves towards a dry finish.  To me, the flavors of this beer were fairly straightforward.  You got a substantial amount of the oak in there, blended nicely with funky brett and acidity, perhaps even some dried fruit (pear?).  Didnt like this one as much as Cantillon Gueze or Rose, though I lack the vocabulary to express how one  Cantillon sour lambic can be truly better than another.  Maybe cause they are all quality.

In a bottle at the Stone Sourfest...the last pour of the last bottle apparently. Pours with a medium clarity gold body and minimal head. Aroma of must and lemon. Taste is sour, vinegar and lemon. Near flat, dry mouthfeel.

Pours almost still, blonde and very hazy. The aroma is dusty with lemons and a very vinous oaky aroma, very good. Flavor is lemon and some vinous characteristics. This is intensely sour and woody and has that sort of musty cob webby thing happening that I love so very much.

Bottle at Stone Sour Fest 09.  Pours a pissy dark yellow with no head.  Looks exactly like a urine sample.  Aroma is bad white wine, vinegar and apple juice.  Flavor is the same cidery apple vinegar wine.  No carbonation and thin on the palate.  I dont want to say this is terrible, but its definitely not good.

Had at Stone Sour Fest 2009. Pours a very clear apple juice color with no head. Acidic aroma of apple cider vinegar. Very flat like a gymnast.with no carbonation. Very weird taste. Overall strange and disappointing like bus-stop drinking fountain water.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2013 Grand Cru Bruocsella Lambic Bio 2005 @Pauls Girardin chugging-courtesy of -750ml bottlepours no head and hazy gold color.  Aroma is funky, tart lemon, light malt.  Taste is earthy, funky, tart lemon, light malt, vinegar.  Minimum carbonation. 3.1 *121201-Cantillon Bruocsella-750ml bottle-Thanks Ron for sharing-still yellow.  A-funk,barn, hay/lt malt.  T-acidic, funk,barn, hay/lt malt.  3.5
Shakeyfest 09. Kinda watery which threw things off a bit. Some good funk. Pretty sour. Good "tanginess"

Bottle 2005, shared by plovmand. 
Pours an hazy yellow with a minimum head. 
Aroma is typical Cantillon and grapes - dry grape, dust, grass and a little humid cellar like. 
Flavour is a little weak but dry and acidic with notes of fruit and wood.
Bottle. Unclear orange body with no head. Dry sour grapes in aroma with some acid and wood. Bit sweet fruity flavour with notes of wood and acid. Medium bodied.

Brewed in Belgium..... Courtesy of AFI96, thanks Waylo !!!  Pours a golden / orange color with zero head. Aroma is of sour apples, lemons and baby funk. Taste of sour fruits, flowers, aspirin and earth. The mouthfeel is super thin in body, zero carbonation and kind of boring. Cantillon makes much better lambics, i suggest you try something else.

Bouteilles datée de 2006 au Bistro lAutre oei. De couleur dorée et bien sur sans mousse ni effervescence. Arôme très sûre et acide avec  des groseilles non mûres, de blé, de la paille, et une ôdeur décurie. Saveur trs semblable à larôme, mais légèrement plus fruitée avec une touche de pamplemousse blanc.

750ml bottle served in a stem glass. Vintage 2008.  Lightly hazed gold, a bit darker than most lambics, with zero head. smell/taste were: barnyard funk, aspirin, lemon, oak, straw and a hint of onion. Palate was thin and slightly astingent. No carbonation. Reminded me of a sour white wine. Doesnt feel as balanced as the blended lambics that Cantillon makes. Also I think I may have liked it better if it had a bit of carbonation.

Bottle at the Thirsty Monk. Pours a translucent gold with no head. The nose is tart and musty, nice yeasty barnyard aromas, acidic, mild phenol with some warmth. Flavor is tart and acidic, a little more one dimensional than a blended lambic, acetic, funky and yeasty, some phenol and astringency on the palate.

Bottle at Lautre Oeil. Bottled date is Oct 08. Pours yellow with no head at all. Aroma is sour with subtle notes of orange, peaches, citrus and lemon.Taste is mild sourness with hints of citrus and lemon. Finish is dry. Palate is dead flat, no carbonation at all. It was enjoyable and tasty but not much complexity. Ive had far better lambic than this one. Maybe I will need to have another sample. The absence of carbonation made it harder to appreciate the beer. A challenging beer like someone just under me said.
chiara piatta il naso è vinoso frutta legno ossidazioni acido in bocca acida secca vinosa fruttata legno frutta secca lunga

Pale golden beer with no head. Sour aroma, woody and herbal, floral, this is a strange bird, reminding me slightly of some white wines but still being quite its own thing entirely. Despite some brett characteristics that remind me that this is indeed a lambic I have never tasted anything like this. A challenging offer from Cantillon.

Cask @ Spuyten Duyvil.  Pours a hazy golden-orange color with a medium-sized white head.  The nose is that Cantillon funk combined with some earthy and grassy notes as well.  Taste is the same, with a wonderful brett/funk finish that completes the whole experience.  Well done, again, Cantillon.

2007 bottle

Maybe Im just not cool enough to enjoy lambics...

Pours a pretty clear yellow-orange with no head.  Smells sour, with a bit of funk, cheese, and some fruit, like apricot.  The flavor is acrid, sour, slightly sweet, slightly funked, with a water aftertaste.  The body of this beer is light.  Overall, its interesting, but I wont buy it again.

750ml Bottle (2007 Vintage):  Aroma of tart fruit, slight funk, oak, slight Brett, and sour acid.  Poured amber/orange in color with no head at all.  Lightly cloudy.  Not sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is lightly sweet and light to moderate tart.  Tastes of oak, tart fruit, slight Brett, wood, and slight barnyard.  Light to medium body.  Thin texture.  Soft carbonation.  Lightly tart, oak finish.

2005 bottle, aged 4 years.  Each pour yields a body that is progressively more cloudy than the last, medium golden-amber in color, with a fleeting, off-white head of bubbles.  Theres virtually no lacing left behind.  The nose is nothing short of stunning, tart apricot showing as the dominant fruit component, with lemon essence, barnyard air, well-used oak, and hints of a dusty old house.  There are hints of nectarine sweetness in there to keep the citric acidity in check, but as refined as it is, theres still no mistaking this as one sour mother of a beer.  Flavors mirror the aroma, tart apricot and zesty lemon calmed ever so slightly by sweet nectarine and hints of juicy peach.  The brief respite from the sourness that the nectarine provides is quickly quashed as brash acidity attacks the throat on the swallow.  Funky oak imparts hints of vanilla and musty wood flavors. This stuff is so refreshing and drinkable, thanks in great part to the lightly carbonated, semi-dry acidity that comes through on the moderate palate.  There simply has to be a good amount of this exact strain in the Cantillon Cuvée des Champions, as the similarities are striking.  Fantastic lambic.

On cask at Spuyten Duyvil at their Cantillon & de la Senne event.  Pours a hazy apricot color with a thin to medium white head.  Lovely funk, with nice notes of hay and wood.  Thin to medium bodied, with light wood flavors.  Excellent sourness with a nice balance of acid and vinegar before a long tart bretty finish.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2009 Bottle 2002. Orange colour with absolutely no head. Very sour, tart, funky, sour fruit, lemon, cheese, oak. Flat with no carbonation to speak of. I need to try this one again in a less intoxicated state.
Thanks to Tom for this one!  Hazy orange pour with no head.  Sour apple and oak aroma.  Leathery, barnyard and perfect acidity

From Cantillon, Brussels, Belgium.
Bottled, 280309.
Orange-amber with no head. Aroma of sour fruits. Flavor is tangy with wood, apple and alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2011 I was able to sample this on tap at Maxs Taphouse in Baltimore during Maxs Belgian fest.  Pours a hazy yellow orange with no head.  Smells both sweet and tart, slightly grassy, some slight funk.  Flavor is grassy, tart, sweet, a touch of that Belgian barnyard funk and some white grapes.  High carbonation in the mouth but also slightly chalky with a lasting tartness.  I very much enjoyed this, probably the best of the day.******** Re-rate, March 2011, 750ml bottle, 2004 vintage.  Pours a hazy, dark yellow with a frothy, white head.  Big, funky aroma, tons of brett, band aid, peppery.  Flavor has loads of lemon, very tart, lemon juice, hay, grass, white grapes, cheesy, limes, white pepper.  Full bodied, tart finish.  Still doing well, some solid acid at the back.

Bottle 750ml.  Pours an orange golden body with a thin white lacing and a thin stream of co2.  Light honey and spices, and woody apple hints.  Citric and lactic acid but not over powering at all.  Some fruity citric notes and light woody funk notes.  This is absolutely delicious, very impressive.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2009 750ml bottle of one surprising lambic that cost me $20. Bottled 09/05/2007. No head, and almost no bubbles. Still, orange, smells musty yet juicy. It tastes like so many different things, juice, apples, sour, must, basement, no wonder gueuze is so good. This lambic did not disappoint.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-15-2009 05:13:07

750ml corked bottle. Lambic Bio 2006. BB September 2028.
Didnt occur to me until I read the label a bit more thoroughly that this was an unblended lambic. I was a bit suprised to see no carbonation on the body, but that explained alot!
Anyway, body is a flat shiny gold, only the slightest haze.
Plenty of tart apple straightup on the nose, unripe stonefruit and lemon rind in there, bit of hay, integrated oak and cheesy funk.
No carbonation which somehow brings a smile to my face, whereas the champagne-like carb of most lambics kind of makes drinking quite an effort. Lengthy palate, nice tongue-coating acid and tannin, with a balancing sweetness.
Lemons, unripe peach, sour apple all seem to emerge nicely on the body. Oak is smooth, lending a hint of vanilla and spice, bitter citrus peel seems to be a constant driving force throughout. Slight cheesy funk towards the finish. Finish is not nearly as brutal as other Cantillons, certainly not as vinegary, still quite tart yet balanced by a nice fruity sweetness.
I found this to be personally the most enjoyable Cantillon to date simply just because of its approachable nature. It still has the traits of a Gueuze, without the brutal carbonation and acid. One would argue its less complex, yes, but I can actually see myself sitting down and enjoying a bottle of this.

750ml bottle via trade a while back.  Pours a clear (on the last glass very cloudy) glowing golden orange with 0 head.  Nose of tart apples with citrus peels and farmhouse funk.  Flavor was both sweet and sour, with a hint of oak in there.  A very underrated Lambic.

Thanks to Cmillward for the taste!  Pours a cloudy golden color.  Aroma is strong funk with apples, pears and lemon rind.  Flavors are more funk and sour fruits with some vanilla and honey.  Very good.

Solid stylistically and overall strong.  A nice sour dough and yeast nose with a slightly cloudy and nearly still pour.  Apples, lychee fruit and grapefruit followed by a sly and the family stone dose of funk.  I approve.

Organic, 2005.  Gold, barely any head.  Looks still in the flute.  Faint on the aroma, some citrus rind, some cherry.  Creamy character, white underripe peach, lasting tart/bitter finish.  Im smiling.

Bottle, sampled at Woodshop Quad. Pours a clear orange with a white ring. Very sour aroma, of citrus, yeast, and malt. Clean sour taste, lots of yeast, under-ripe citrus, and malt. Big lingering crisp sourness. Really nice.

This rating is for the Bruocsella 1900. I tried this at the first BA Nashville tasting alongside a 2002 Bruocsella Grand Cru. Pours honey golden with no head. Aroma of Belgian "barnyard" funk. Flavor has a medium to strong sourness, along with some honey and grassiness. There is enough sweetness to keep this drinkable. Not bad. Now for the 2002 Grand Cru (not rated), it had much more of the less desireable barnyard qualities in the  aroma. Bugs had done their thing and made this far less sweet and more dry, making it far too acetic for my tastes. 8-3-7-4-14
Golden orange in color with no head. Aroma is fruity and tart. Taste is slightly subdued with light fruit, oak and tartness.

On Tap at Maxs Belgian Festival in Baltimore.  What a great lambic.  Pours a muddy yellow color with almost no head.  Aroma is that perfect sour beer stank with some hosre blanket action going on.  Flavor is a wonderful mouth puckering sour citrus fruit tart hot mess. . . but in a very good way.  Some good oak tannin flavor hiding in the background too.  This was a nice beer.

Draft, on handpump at Monks cafe. Pours hazy golden, with minimal off-white head. Aroma is mildly tart, with notes of mild citrus and wood. Flavor is tart, with notes of citrus, especially grapefruit, apple, and wood. Fairly flat. This is very drinkable, but I dont find it as complex as most other Cantillons.
On tap @ Maxs BBF. Pours a hazy amber color with no head. Woody esters dominate the aroma; sweet oaked body with a sour finish. Not bad, but not up to Cantillon standards.
The perfect beer.  I hope that people who dont understand lambics stop pulling the average rating of this fantastic liquid down.  A stinky, deep, ineffable beauty of a beer.
Ive been very impressed with Cantillon beers, but this one was disappointing. Not particularly drinkable or enjoyable.

750ml bottle from High Time Wine.  Pours with a few bubbles, but flat.  Had to question whether it was supposed to be this flat or if I got a bad bottle.  Aroma was of strong oak (expected after aging three years in a barrel) with a hint of tartness - apples perhaps - and some malt.  Color is clear, crisp, gold with again, no bubbles to speak of.Flavors are intensly lambic, oaks, woods, but a bit too much like a cider or wine.  The tartness of the citrus comes through at the end, a satisfying finish, but in the end, I felt it lacking overall.

Hazy honey yellow with a thin splash of bubbles but essentially flat.  Lots of tart acidity and oak in the aroma.  Feels flat on the tongue with a big oak note before the drying finish of acidity that draws the saliva out of your mouth.  Nice citrus and apple cider undertones as well.

22oz bottle. Pours clear gold, no head, no carbonation, we even tried to force some by giving a hard pour. This was our first unblended lambic. The nose is very oaky, tons of wood, with some tart apples. The taste is a little tart but very smooth and flat, reminds me a bit of the great Spanish Cider Sagardoa. Very different and we sipped on this beer all night long as a palate cleanser in between big imperial stouts.
Pours out clear gold with no head. Smells funky, oaky and sweet. Taste is  apple juice like. Funky yeast and notes of wood. Nice dry finish. Great old lambic taste. Tasty

AlohaC’s gathering.  Smells really sweet.  Pineapple and grapes.  Light amber and cloudy.  Taste is full and tart.  Not a sharp pucker of flavor.  It feels like it is pulling all the saliva from my mouth.  Leaves me with a dry mouth.
interesting nose very cantilionesc....and no carbonation....but still nice to try and unblended lambic!

Bottled sample, 2001 vintage. Medium gold in colour with zero carbonation. Aromas of citrus infused funk, old wood, a bit of earth, and a hint of pale malt. More funky and dry than sour in the mouth, with increasing earth and somewhat cheese like flavors. Some citrus and wood remain. Enjoyable, but not my favorite Cantillon product.

750 cl. from 2001. Pours a golden hazyness like an ecological apple-cider with only a tiny head around the edge. The nose is fresh and fine with hiuntsa of citrus and pinecones, almonds and alcohol. The taste is all sour without any really complexiness. Sweet grapefruits isall im thinking of. The finish is sweetand sour and fading away smoothly.

750 ml at the brewery.  Sorry, the museum.  You need to like lambics to like this one.  Head was limited to 3 bubbles.  Musty nose with citrus.  Medium body, acidic and sour.  Grows on you.  And maybe in you.

I didnt get Cantillon until I got this. 

750ml 2006 vintage uncorked by priapic cherub. Burnished gold with faint mist. You dont need me to tell you its as fizzless as apple juice, but that its as solidly bodied is a surprise. Complex sweet aromas of honey, lemon, lime, apple juice, glowing fireside single malt mellowed in oak fora couple of decades. Nothing especially barnyardy or acetic. Dustily clean, cleanly dusty. Some kind of antiseptic dentists waiting room note.  Almost apple bubblegum fruitiness, considering. Overwhelmingly honey. That this is conjured from the use of water, wheat, barley, dried hops, oak, and (not so) randomly floating wild yeast is a miracle of brewing in itself. Brewers of foul allegedly honeyed confections take note. Piques with acidity, but isnt ferocious. None of the heartburn tartness I was expecting. Not until the third glass, anyway. The years in wood and glass seems to have restored some of the mellow woodsy apple and lemon notes you might find in an unspicy dry witbier. Wheat and mildly puckering apple all the way. Honey and oak leaping out. Occasional swig of Brie creaminess, vanilla, peat. The mellowest, most complex, most delicious unblended lambic Ive tasted. Could savour it geekishly or glug it by the pint. 

Astonishing and unprecedented. 

(4am election night toast in honour of Obama.)
Bottle.  Pours a golden yellow color that is slightly hazy.  Smells slightly sour with a nice fruit and earth smell.  Tastes similar with sourness first and then sweet.  Very mild carbonation.

1999 Vintage from Bier Circus in Brussels. Color is golden yellow with subtle shades of brown. Aroma is sour but dry, with an earthiness and a slight burnt aroma. Mild carbonation. First taste is overwhelmingly sour, with some tart mixed in, and musty on the finish, with a lingering mustiness not like other lambics I’ve had. Perhaps the bottle was past its prime?

2007 bottle. Pours a tepid golden amber, no head but a few bubbles in ring, dull body. Pretty unappealing. Sour nose of must and sweat, slight cheese, and faint lemon. Tart flavor is musty lemon, a little earth, and a nice grape sweetness as a balance. With warmth additional flavors unfold for a tart and biting yet sweet and refreshing combination. Mouth is dry and thin, a little watery, and short-lived, the grape lasting longest. Very nice beer, but too weak in certain areas to warrant undying affection.

(bottle, vintage 2003, thanks JK!) Pours a still, cloudy gold.  Aroma contains a lot of cut grass, oak, yeast, and salty, funky cheese.  The taste is lightly sour, with some funky cheese, lemon, but becomes far more salty towards the finish which I did not really care for.

Bottle, bought in Ølbutikken, Cph. [my 3,800th rating] Pours hazy orange-yellow with no head. Aroma is fruity, funky, some egg-notes amongst apples and oranges. Very low carbonation, wonderful dry mouthfeel. Pleasantly tart flavour, lots of apple fruitiness, vanilla, lots of oak, barnyeard and hay. Super, dry finish.
No head or carbonation to speak of.  Orange like color.  Very clear.  Very champagne like.  Smell is tart, fruity, sour, and a little funk.  Taste is sour and makes you want more.  Very dry.

January 2007 vintage 750 ml. into wine glass.  Hazy orange no head (no carbonation) but some white froth swirling on surface.  Aroma is nice and champagne like - white grapes, yeast, natural alcohol, sourness - not that complex to my nose, but nice and tempting.  Flavor is good and way more balanced and smooth than my previous (and first) sour - Marriage parfait.  Sweet on front with nice sour follow through that lingers but not in a puckering way but a unique way I cant really explain (kind of takes over your mouth).  Thin to medium body - great on palate for me since I am not a huge carbonation fan... this thing is nearly flat.  Overall:  great style when done like this.

Cloudy golden with fast dissapering head. Strong woody aroma  with notes of horseblanket and leather. Grapefruit develops in mouth. Flavour starts sweet and then sournesss and  tartness takes over. Long sour finish.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle, vintage 2003.  Thanks John!  A still, rusty orange pour.  Lemon curd and custard aroma; lavender, goat cheese, and funk laid low and quiet, subject to its refined characters of sweetness and delicate earth, with a touch of puckering fresh grapefruit acidity.  A dull grassy sourness, strawlike and quite plain, in the flavor, lacking even a hint of traditional confrontational funkiness right away; rather, its mostly a briny saltwater with a distant hint of fruit skins and leafiness.  Late hints of white pepper, cinnamon, and cellar stink as it approaches room warmth.  Light-medium palate, watery and dusty; finishes with some gruyere rind, earthy salts, and maybe seaweed; certainly quite green and still salty, whatever it is.  Though its quite tranquil, its calmness is not hard to appreciate; a lambic with plenty of funkiness and less sourness, and thats fine.

Bottle opened by Douglas88, thanks for the brew mi amigo. You know, when you rate an Imperial Stout or an IPA you can draw from lifes experiences to describe the flavors or aromas.Hell, espresso, molasses, citrus, those are all things you can explain. But when a Lambic comes along and me being a city boy and never had a wet nasty horse blanket tossed drapped over my shoulders like Jeremiah Johnson might have, then how can use that as a descriptor? I do not know what the damn thing "smelt" like or even tasted like but it was a-fuckinging-mazing.

2007 vintage bottle. Pours out with no pop when de-corking and no head at all. A vigorous pours sees some bubbles floating around. A cloudy deep yellow color. The aroma is a sour perfume-like and woody note. The initial taste is sour, but not anywhere near some of the others I’ve had, such as the Iris. Instead, a strong funky sourness is alongside a smooth and full sawdust flavor. As it warms a ton of flavor is released, mostly more wood infused sourness, some slight funky and citrus. Quite good. Something original and pure. Though it has no head, the body is somehow smooth and nice. It also goes down quite well.

22oz Bottle. Pours yellow with no head or carbonation at all. Aroma is nice... fruits, spices, citrus, wet blanket, and hints of wood. Taste was really less than what I had hoped for. Must vinegar, funk, and light fruit flavors. Of all the lambics that I have tried this is most certianly not one of my favorites.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2008 2006 vintage, draught. Pours clear gold with a slight orange tint, no head. Nose is musty, leather, earthy, barnyard, sour apple, with an underlying sharp citric note. Taste is soft, musty barnyard sourness, sour apple and leather, hint of citric bite. Mouthfeel is still, almost no carbonation, medium bodied.

(Bottle, brewed 2005 bottled 2008, Akkurat, Stockholm 16 Aug 2008) Bronze coclour with no head, very little carbonation. Tart, citric, fruity nose with grapefruit, stable and horse blanket. Tart, fruity taste with notes of green apples, grapefruit and unripe gooseberries. Lack of carbonation makes it rather flat, but smooth and easy to drink despite its tartness and dryness. Very nice beer.

Bottled 2007.  Hazy orange body, no head formed.  Aroma is of vinegar, sour, caramely sweetness, and a woody perfume.  The flavor is a strange mixture of slightly sour with woody, cheese rind bitter note.  Smooth, without much bite, either sour or bitter.  The flavor is actually subdued as to appear watered down, without being so.  A kind of caramel or light fruity sweetness towards the finish.
No head at all, lemon rind nose. very drying mouthfeel, yellow color with small chunks floating around. not my fav Lambic.
This beer pours a hazy amber with no distinctive aroma.  The flavor is that of tart apple, not overbearing,. but pleasing to the palate.

Bottle 75 cl. The first impression was: how am I going to drink the whole bottle. It had a heavy aroma of sulfur and a heavy bitter finish. After a while and after the beer got a higher temperature (10-15), the beer got better and better - but never one of my favourites. The beer has a spare white fast diminishing head. The body is hazy and orange and has lightly particles. The aroma is harsh hops, citrus, earth, wine, vinegar, basement. It has a light body, thin texture, flat carbonation and a bitter finish. The flavor is light sweet and heavy bitter and acidic.
75cl bottle 2005 edition. Really nice thick yellow color. Taste is a bit acid with some citrus notes. Not really my kind of beer,

(2005 vintage, Draught at Tuulensuu, Tampere, on 2008-07-26) Gollden. Hazy. Tiny white head that disappeared quickly. Sour, fruity and lightly wooden nose. Acidy palate, dry, medium-bodied. Wood, sourness, fruitiness, vomit and bitterness in taste. Long balanced aftertaste. Nice.
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2014 75cl, Vintage 2010, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex sour brew, balanced, hazy, nearly no head, good lambic

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2009 I was shocked I liked this, because I wasnt a true lambic fan.  But man was this nice.  Forget where I got the bottle, but it was bottled Jan 07 and I had it July 08 (it was the Organic).  Pours even with no head or carbonation - the best color I have yet seen in a sour, lambic or geuze.  Brilliant flavor that is deep and not tart (I think the lack of carb. helps a lot to trim the edge off the flavor): mustard, unripe peach, green grape peels, very slight wood, and lemon peel.  Only had a couple ounces, but I was impressed and will find this one again.

Unblended real lambic?  One of a kind?  Sounds like an essential experience for any lambic lover, and I count myself in their ranks.  I’m intoxicated immediately after the pour.  Once the light amber amber is out, the aroma immediately wafts into the nose without a head to impede it - just a few lurking bubbles, like sharks in an empty sea.  It hit hards with a strong column of boozy vapors, along with an oak woodiness, and whispers of peach, flower petals, oranges, nectarine and a subtle potpourri.  As for the taste, it’s an acquired one.  At first its like drinking public pool water, sort of flat, faint and awkwardly sweet.  It stays in this unpleasant state until swallowed, at which point the tongue is aglow in a sophisticated sweet and spiced alcoholic burn, and its worth the price of that initial flavor.  I also catch lime and oak in this very hazy aftertaste, but I can definitely confirm it is a delicious aftertaste, and where all of the Cantillon Bruoscella’s merits are collected.

NO head whatsoever.   My first unblended lambic.  I have drank lake superior lambics and this is something completely different.  It resembles the sour tartness of a straight lemon and has a subtle similarity to true apple cider.  This drink is a unique beverage that is truly one of a kind.  Every beer lambic fan should add this one to their list.

Bottle thanks to Woodsman52.  All I can really say is "whoa".  I first tasted a lambic style beer over a year ago and this is the first one Ive tried since then. I forgot how intense these beers can be.  Has a hazy yellow color with almost no head at all.  Extremely sour, tart, flavor with some citrus backbone. Has a long lasting after taste that.  If you arent used to drinking lambics, its difficult to get past the sourness of this beer.  But I can appreciate the intensity and complexity.

Bottle thanks to bigmmartin.  Slightly hazy golden with very little head.  Sour aroma.  I’m not the biggest fan of lambics or sour flavors but I’ll try to be unbiased.  Slightly sweet upfront with extreme sourness throughout that lasts.  Otherwise smooth on the palate.  This reminds me of sour green apples.  This is not my favorite style but its not bad compared to other lambics I’ve tried.

Same sample pour as Brigadier at the Beer Engine.  I concur with most of his observations however, I would comment on the low to almost non-existent carbonation.  The acidity/sourness of the lambic more than makes up for this in the mouthfeel.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2013 4 oz sample

I had the chance to try this at the Buckeye Beer Engine during a special sour ale sampling.  It was worth every penny of the $3 I paid.  Given the cost for a full 750ml I probably wont be springing for one any time soon even if I could find it.  Even so if I happen to run across this again I will certainly not pass it up.

Aroma / Appearance - The honey colored body was flat and lifeless.  The scent of dry white wine tickled the nose along with an orange base, white grapes and an oaky base.  For a lambic it was very gentle.

Flavor / Palate - The tartness was not nearly as strong as I thought it would be.  Sour, dry and a little woody it was chewy and dense.  As expected it did dry out the throat.  Reminding me of a dry white wine it was excellent all the way to the final drop.

Bhensonb shared a bottle with me. This golden lambic poured with no head at all, eliciting an acidic aroma. There is a gentle flavor - neither sweet nor sour. One is left with a slightly sour citrus taste on the tongue. This is just a straight, unblended lambic, yet it is very tasty. Thanks Bill.

750 ml bottle. Bottled 05 Sept 2007. Hazy orange amber color with no real head. Slightly acidic aroma. Rather thin, with no carbonation. Flavor is mildly acidic with a little light stone fruit and some citrus. Finish is about the same, but a little wood is detectable. Its a very good drink. It seems to go well with cheese and nuts.

Bottle 2005:Cloudy deep orange with just about no head. Nice nose. Overall citric acidity, with leather, soft grapefruit notes, musty damp basement. Not much carbontation, very slick. Flavor is less sour than expected. Tart lemon character with an overall citric acidity. Has some leather, dust, oak tannins and a clean acidic finish. Not the most complex Cantillon but nice. This is only my second unblended and I dont think I enjoy them as much as blended Lambics.

[Bottle] shared at the Heritage Inaugural Tasting by Anya. Pours a clear straw gold with little to no head. Smells like skunk, brett, and maybe some cannabis. thin mouthfeel with a pungent sourness. Maybe a little past its prime, as it was a little watery and didnt quite smell right.
Strong oak vinegar lambic aroma. Golden yellow color.  Oak, vinegar, sour fruit, leather flavors.  Flat palate with vinegary duration.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2008 Vintage 2003, 37.5cl. Golden, no head. Sharp sour aroma, cellar and a lot of barnyard. Tart, cellary flavor with earth and apple seeds. Sediment adds a tannic bite & a bit of grapefruit. Flat palate. In the end this felt somehow gentle, probably due to the lack of carbonation.

edit. Had this one again the other night. Ammonium, funk, cellar and sourness. A beer for the connoisseurs, medieval in a glass.

Cask at Spuyten Duyvil. Unremarkable aroma, just funk. Light fruity notes, even berries, in the flavor with some funk. Grows while in the glass. Lack of carbonation doesnt help the mouthfeel. Decent.

On cask at Spuyten Duyvil Brett Fest, organic version.  Pours a light orange with no head.  Aroma is fruity, but I cant tell which fruit.  Flavor of sour funk, oak/wood, cheese.  No carbonation.  This beer had too much funk/sweat and I was not a fan.  Seems that its better in bottle.
On cask at Spuyten Duyvil Brett Fest.  Hazy orange flat.  Dishwater lemon funk aroma.  Flavor like lemon-apple cider poured over a horses balls.  Funky.
cask at spuytin duvil durring Brett fest in Brooklyn . Smells like chubakahs armpit, extreme funk. No carbonation, surprisingly fruity, sour/ tart back end.

interesting, cask.  a nice study in simplicity.  slightly below average, shows us that lambic does take a fair amount of finesse.  no so sour not much doing simple cirtus and mild in terms of the sour.

Big thanks to Fin for this bottle! Vintage 2005. Warm orange pour with just a touch of haze, a little scattering of white bubbles. To smell: a few Holstein cows graze on rich green grass. Downwind, vines loaded with unctuous spicy wild muscat grapes, bright in the fall sun and dusted in yellow goldenrod pollen. Sharp grapeskin musky tart bite. No, not quite right: there is a sharp flinty grapeskin quality to the flavor, but the tartness is actually quite soft. Esp for a Cantillon beer, which to my palate often push the acidity a bit far. Grass, iodine, salt. Very fine carbonation, just a hint of tiny peppery fizz. At first I think, could use more, then I think maybe this is just right. Very refreshing and lovely. A cracking good beer. Thanks again Fin!

Pretty average here in terms of Cantillon. Ive come to really adore the puckering dry sourness that I associate with Cantillon. This was a nice beer, albeit a bit boring for them. The aroma was lemony, horsey and quite suprisingly fruity. The flavor is almost delicate for Cantillon, which seems odd just typing that. Lemony, oak, citrusy twang, and funk. Not really up to Cantillons famous sour power, but still a very nice beer.

Bottle from Mystery Swap 3.0. Pours a hazy golden color with no head at all. Aroma of grapefruit, lemons, green apples. Has an earthy ,sour smell to it. Taste is sour, earthy and semi tart. A very nice, different, complex brew!

bottle from beverage castle in tampa. pours an orangish color, similar to apple juice. the aroma is pretty much lemon juice in comparison, i like the smell of lemon juice but wow this stuff is tart, and very acidic. so after tasting it, it was like a shock to my senses. i had no idea what i was about to taste, and it was crazy! so sour and tart, and then you can taste the oak, i have no idea what to compare this to after tasting it, maybe lemon juice aged in oak. this is good because its different and like nothing else ive tasted but honestly i dont know if i can say ill drink this style again.

Bottle shared at Sean and Ryans tasting in May. Ive waited some time to try this one, since bottles are quite expensive. As an unblended lambic, appearances can be deceiving. Pours dead still, with a hazy straw yellow color that looks like apple juice. Awesome aroma and flavor however; very smooth tones of lemon peel, barnyard, oak wood and subtle transitions in the flavor towards a perfect amount of tartness and funk. Ultra-velvety palate and the lactic sour finish is spot-on. Really an impressive lambic.
Bottle, pours hazy pale orange with no head. Nose is soft and tart fruit, as is the flavor. Very light and delicate on the palate. Smooth and refreshing.
bottle again thanks to tom- pours hazy golden amber, no head. smells subtle nose of pear, citrus, peach tastes watered down peach, grapefruit lemon. delicously gluggable.

17 Jan 2007 bottling date. Hazy orange with no head. Great smell is hay, grassy, dandelions, wood. Flat mouthfeel with no carbonation. Flavors are wood hay grass cracker malt grains. Really not that sour up front or mid palate, with an acidic aspirin burn in the finish.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: bottle from brewery.    Pours flat apple juice flavored color, smells of apple, grapes and vinegary sourness.  Very smooth and buttery taste, oaky, mild sourness, a little dry.  Pretty mild taste.  Might need to age a bit, but still a very interesting beer.

Courtesy-Degarth
A-Funk, Oak,Grapes and Fruit zest
AP- Cloudy orange,with no head to speak of but guite pretty
F- Wow this is very funky. Tastes of oak, and grapes
P- Sharp and abrasive

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2015 Re-rate 7/15: Bottle sample at sour tasting at Noams office. Thanks Vova & Stas. 2012 bottle. Huge oak, funk leather, sourish, astringent, quite a bit of bitterness. Could use a few more years in the bottle. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4

Re-rate 2/8/12: Bottle sample at the 2nd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks beerandbeyond. Slightly hazy golden with no head. Aroma of barnyard, citrus and oak. Sour (yet not VERY sour, somewhat mild) flavor with lots of oak, fruits and a bone-dry finish. Great - delicate and quaffable. 8/3/8/4/16=3.9

Re-rate 7/3/11: Bottle sample at the 1st Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks Lee. Clear golden. Lovely aroma of barnyard with a bit of sweat. Delicate sour flavor with a bitter finish of citrus peels. Flat mouthfeel the give nice easy drinkability. 8/3/8/4/16=3.9

(3/12/08) Bottle at Chez Moeder Lambic in Brussels. Bottled 9/5/07. Dirty golden with no head. Funky sour oak aroma. The flavor is sour but not super-sour like a lot of other Cantillon beers, with soft bretty character, wood and a finish with some citrus. Medium body and a rounded mouthfeel. Maybe a bit too mild but great, I think it could be amazing in a few more years. 8/3/8/4/16=3.9

Bottle picked this up at Dranken Geers, Gent had 24-03-08   Poured as flat as a pancake, no fizz, sparkle no nothing. Nose is musty, oaky, and a bit farmyardy also very soft lemony. The taste is initially a real lemony bite but much softer around the edges than other Cantillon, nice looking orange amber colour with some haze. Quite tart and then finished with sour dryness, this has been a difficult one for me to rate as I was totally shocked by the non-carbonation but I got used to it after a while.

Bottle (75cl): Golden, no head; solid mouldy, cellary nose, brett as well; robust dry, sour-tart flavour, light bodied; green apples, wheat and a huge acidity in the finish. Masochists like this "beer"......

Cloudy Orange-amber pour with no head and no carbination.  Definitely lemon/lime aroma.  Cantillon lies!!  This is wine not beer.  Watery mouthfeel with no carbonation.  Acidic finish with slight woody notes.  I like it but I dont love it maybe I dont have a taste for this yet.  I keep wanting the warming of the wine but it never comes.  I just get this weird sourness.

Courtesy of Naka. Hazy orange body with no head and no carbonation. Incredibly funky smell with lemon and orange fruity notes mixed with extreme sour/brett smells. Also smells bready and slightly nutty. Super acidic, horse blanket taste with a puckering, lemony acidic finish. Amazing complexity, with subtleties and nuances revealed in each sip. Perfectly still in the mouth. A truly beautiful beer.

What an interesting beer, certainly like nothing Ive had before. Pours a light orange or amber, obviously no head and completely still.  Nose is muscat grapes, apples, noticeable yeast tones in barnyard, cob-webbed mustiness, and a bit of rubber.  Taste is upfront citric sourness as well as some floral notes, some hay, tannic character, finishes with dusty, earthy hops and a lasting sourness. Finishes sour and dry. No carbonation, maintains a moderately full mouthfeel despite lack of carbonation.  Pretty awesome and totally unique.

3/15/08 - Courtesy of Naka, shared with Naka and santoslhalper.  Pours hazy orange with no carbonation whatsoever.  Nose is sour and funky Brett, sour apple and sweet green grape.  Its pungent, stings the nostrils.  Taste is sour and citric acid, lemon, orange, touch of apple.  some sourdough bread-type-thing.  So complex, Im not sure if Im ready for this.  Just good stuff in small doses.  Dry finish, champagne-esque.  Good.

On tap at Ortinos Northside.  Pours a mostly translucent golden with orange almost pinkish notes and a very small bubbly white head.  Aroma of citrus, floral notes, barnyard, funky and tart with like acetic nots.  Flavor was lightly tart and funky, some of the barnyard/horse blanket, dry and actually a little thin.

My first experience with unblended lambic.  Pours a hazy orange peach color with no head at all. Has an aroma of rye, sauerkraut, and some other general funk.  Wow is the taste sour.  It has a really dry funky taste.  My palate is too green to do the complexity justice.  Has some acidic lemony citrus taste to it.  Finishes like a flat champagne.  My head is spinning try to describe this.

(75cl bottle, vintage 2002) Slightly hazy, pale golden colour without a head. Sour and apple fruity nose with woody barrel-like notes and traces of brett. Sour flavour, oxidative slightly wheaty taste, apple fruity with traces of horseblanket; bone-dry and sourish tart, lasting finish. Refreshing Lambic, that reminds me somewhat of the best applewines from the Hessian Wetterau (12.03.08).

2-24-08 bottle shared at tasting 
Slightly cloudy yellow orange with NO head.  Smell is strong, sour and funky!  Very musky (like dirty socks and sweaty clothes musky).  Sweet flavor.  No carbonation at all - but I dont know that I really miss it here.  Still quite tart overall.  I actaully started to enjoy the strange mouthfeel.  Overall, not horrid

Golden-orange, apricot color with virtually no head or apparent carbonation.

Sour barnyard smell with sweet fruity tartness.

Tart, musty barnyard with sour lactic acid impression, not much fruit.

Non-carbonation works surprisingly well for this sour, interesting change from the aggressive foaming of say, a geuze with similar flavors.

On tap at Maxs. The unltimate blonde. Great creaminess with a vanilla accent. Very light carbonation. Sourness is wonderful with a glimpse of apricots. All of this wrapped up in a slightly woody package. Grerat beer!

Orco boia. Bottiglia da 75cl al Duca; non avevo mai assaggiato lambic "liscio" e per me è stata una bella botta, nonostante io sia un ammiratore del genere. Laspetto me lo aspettavo: niente schiuma (proprio 0), torbido, non era una grossa sorpresa, e a suo modo è alquanto apprezzabile: laroma neppure è stato una sorpresa, anzi, molto vicino alla gueuze anche se un poco più pungente. Ma il sapore è stato già una conquista maggiore, acido senza la confortante e carezzevole frizzantezza della gueuze, morto come un mare morto, paludoso, espettorante, wowville; 75cl da solo sono stati un po pesanti da finire, ma lo rifarei, magari stavolta in compagnia (dico in compagnia a bere, non che ieri sera fossi da solo).

Slightly hazy golden pour with zero head whatsoever.  Smells like a dirty medicated band-aid.  Musty, funky, bacteria laden.  Taste is completely bland, acidic tartness.  No balancing malt.  Zero carbonation and feels like drinking rancid bile water.  Completely not my style, and I found this very offensive overall, unfortunately.

Finally getting a rating for this beer. A generous BA person bought a bottle of this at a small "tasting" I was doing with EDA. Big funk, super cheesy and horsey brett aroma. Flavor is a bit thin, a bit of sour, with a carpet-y flavor. Very still, a little dull, but not bad at all. Unblended lambics arent really my thing, but they are always fun to try.

pours a flat gold with no carbonation and no head.  sour sweet bret aroma, flat and mild palate, relatively light sourness and subtle complexity.  watery loose palate and mild hidden background.  amazingly sessionable quality behind a hidden complexity.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2008 Completely opaque orange-amber pour.  Very thick with no carbonation - looks like grapefruit juice.  Woody lemon aroma with lots of vinegar.  Fruity with lots of funky earth notes.  Lemony sour flavor.  Very fruity without all the vinegar that was present in the aroma.  A bit of a creamy oak flavor as well.  The citrus is very intense and sour.  A bit of fruitiness and a bitter finish, almost like sucking on a lemon peel.  The sourness is almost overpowering, but very good and enjoyable.  I’ve had lambics that had more sourness, but this definitely isn’t for the faint of heart.  It’s also complete flat, but still very good.

2004 bottle. Low carbonation. Nose of apple cider, barnyard and honey. Not as acidic as expected (for Cantillon standards), yet tart and mouth-watering, woody and dry. The mouthfeel is mellow and smooth. The finale has great finesse. Much more interesting than a 2004 bottle tasted in 2006... Very statisfying. Pairs very well with sushis.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2008 375ml bottle (Apteeki, Turku)
Sharp and sweet aroma, a little fruity - citrus, grapefruity, woody, musky. Puckeringly sharp. Citrus and grapefruity taste, hebs, woody, oaky.
previous rating: 7-3-7-3-15=3.5
375ml bottle (St. Urhos, Helsinki) 2005 vintage (sip - thanks mirjukka!)
Flat orange or light brown. The usual Cantillon fingerprint is easily detected on your nose, but this one is  mellower. Youre definitely facing a sour lambic, but this is very woody indeed, very soft and mellow. Its soft in the mouth despite the sharpness. Apricot is the most prominent taste, but theres the classic Cantillon lambic body backing that up, and it leaves an oaky woody and walnut-paper nutty finish. Classic Cantillon, but this is a little thin and watery as its too young. Must rerate in a couple of years.

Earlier Rating: 7/4/2007 Total Score: 3.9Bottle (Apteekki, Turku) 2003 vintage.
Slightly cloudy dark yellow, completely flat. Wondrous lightly sour and refreshingly sweet aroma. Buttered hot cross buns. Taste is refreshingly sharp sour bitterness which leaves a wonderfully mellow malt taste, a little bit like buttered hot cross buns too. Dont let the barstaff take your empty glass away, as even that smells beautiful!
